v2/AnnouncementBannerApi/getBanner: The `getBanner` endpoint in the `AnnouncementBannerApi` retrieves the current announcement banner configuration. It requires the "Administer Jira" global permission and can be used to get the current announcement banner settings.
v2/AnnouncementBannerApi/setBanner: The `setBanner` endpoint of the `AnnouncementBannerApi` allows you to update the announcement banner configuration in Jira. The endpoint requires an `AnnouncementBannerConfigurationUpdate` object as a parameter and returns an unspecified type. This endpoint would be used by administrators with the "Administer Jira" global permission to modify the announcement banner settings in their Jira instance.
v2/AppDataPoliciesApi/getPolicies: The `getPolicies` endpoint in the `AppDataPoliciesApi` retrieves the data policies for the specified project IDs. It takes an optional `ids` parameter as a comma-separated list of project identifiers, and returns a `ProjectDataPolicies` object. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve the data policies associated with specific projects.
v2/AppDataPoliciesApi/getPolicy: The `getPolicy` endpoint of the `AppDataPoliciesApi` retrieves the data policy for the current workspace. This would be used to fetch the workspace's data policy configuration, which may include settings related to data retention, access controls, and other policy-related properties.
v2/AppMigrationApi/appIssueFieldValueUpd: The `appIssueFieldValueUpdateResource.updateIssueFieldsPut` endpoint allows Connect apps to bulk update the values of custom fields added by Connect apps on one or more issues. The update is performed using the `Atlassian-Transfer-Id` header and a `ConnectCustomFieldValues` object that specifies the new field values. This endpoint is typically used when a Connect app needs to update custom field data on multiple issues.
v2/AppMigrationApi/migrationResource.upd: The `migrationResource.updateEntityPropertiesValuePut` endpoint is used to bulk update the values of multiple entity properties for an object during an app migration. It supports updating up to 50 properties per request and requires the `Atlassian-Transfer-Id` and `entityType` parameters, which indicate the migration transfer ID and the type of object containing the properties, respectively.
v2/AppMigrationApi/migrationResource.wor: The `migrationResource.workflowRuleSearchPost` endpoint retrieves the configurations of workflow transition rules that have been migrated from Jira Server to Jira Cloud and are owned by the calling Connect app. It takes a `WorkflowRulesSearch` object as input and returns a `WorkflowRulesSearchDetails` object. This endpoint is useful when you need to access and manage the workflow rules that have been migrated as part of an app migration process.
v2/AppPropertiesApi/addonPropertiesResou: The `addonPropertiesResource.deleteAddonPropertyDelete` endpoint allows you to delete a property associated with a specific app. It requires the `addonKey` and `propertyKey` parameters, and the requesting app must have the appropriate permissions to access the app's properties. This endpoint is useful when you need to remove a specific property from an app's configuration.

The `addonPropertiesResource.getAddonPropertiesGet` endpoint retrieves all the properties of an app, identified by the `addonKey` parameter. This endpoint is used to access the app's properties, and can be accessed by the app itself or by Forge apps that are associated with the same `app.connect.key`. The response is a `PropertyKeys` object containing the app's properties.

The `addonPropertiesResource.getAddonPropertyGet` endpoint retrieves the key and value of an app's property. It requires the app key and property key as parameters, and is used by Connect apps or Forge apps to access the properties of a Connect app. The response is an `EntityProperty` object.

The `addonPropertiesResource.putAddonPropertyPut` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to set the value of an app's property. This can be used to store custom data for your app. The request body must be a valid, non-empty JSON blob with a maximum length of 32768 characters. This endpoint requires authentication either through OAuth2 or basic authentication, and is restricted to the Connect app whose key matches the `addonKey` parameter or Forge apps that can access Connect app properties.
v2/AppPropertiesApi/deleteForgeAppProper: The `deleteForgeAppProperty` endpoint in the AppPropertiesApi allows Forge apps to delete a property associated with the app. The only required parameter is the `propertyKey`, which specifies the key of the property to be deleted. This endpoint is useful when you need to remove a specific property associated with your Forge app.
v2/AppPropertiesApi/getForgeAppProperty: The `getForgeAppProperty` endpoint retrieves the value of a Forge app's property. It requires the `propertyKey` parameter to specify the property key, and can only be accessed by Forge apps using the `asApp()` request method. This endpoint would be used when a Forge app needs to access its own property values.
v2/AppPropertiesApi/getForgeAppPropertyK: The `getForgeAppPropertyKeys` endpoint in the AppPropertiesApi retrieves all the property keys for a Forge app. This endpoint is used to access the Forge app's properties and can only be accessed using the `asApp()` request from Forge. It requires specific permissions and returns a `getForgeAppPropertyKeys_200_response` object.
v2/AppPropertiesApi/putForgeAppProperty: The `putForgeAppProperty` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to set the value of a Forge app's property. These property values can be retrieved in Jira expressions and used in entity property display conditions. The request body must be a valid, non-empty JSON blob with a maximum length of 32768 characters. This API can only be accessed using `asApp()` requests from Forge apps, and the `write:app-data:jira` OAuth scope is recommended, though not currently required.
v2/ApplicationRolesApi/getAllApplication: The `getAllApplicationRoles` endpoint in the Jira API returns a list of all application roles. Application roles are used to manage access to Jira applications and features. This endpoint requires the "Administer Jira" global permission and can be used to retrieve the available application roles for administrative purposes.
v2/ApplicationRolesApi/getApplicationRol: The `getApplicationRole` endpoint in the ApplicationRolesApi retrieves a specific application role in Jira, identified by its key. It requires the "Administer Jira" global permission and returns an `ApplicationRole` object. This endpoint is useful when you need to fetch information about a particular application role, such as its name or description.
v2/AuditRecordsApi/getAuditRecords: The `getAuditRecords` endpoint in the AuditRecordsApi retrieves a list of audit records that can be filtered by various parameters such as `offset`, `limit`, `filter`, `from`, and `to`. This endpoint is useful for administrators to audit and review user actions and changes within Jira. The API requires the "Administer Jira" global permission.
v2/AvatarsApi/deleteAvatar: The `deleteAvatar` endpoint in the AvatarsApi allows you to delete an avatar associated with a project, issue type, or priority in Jira. It requires the `Administer Jira` global permission and takes in the avatar type, the ID of the owning object (e.g., project), and the ID of the avatar to be deleted. This endpoint is useful when you need to remove an avatar that is no longer needed or appropriate for a particular Jira entity.
v2/AvatarsApi/getAllSystemAvatars: The `getAllSystemAvatars` endpoint in the AvatarsApi retrieves a list of system avatars based on the specified owner type (issue type, project, user, or priority). This operation can be accessed anonymously and requires no specific permissions.
v2/AvatarsApi/getAvatarImageByID: The `getAvatarImageByID` endpoint retrieves a project, issue type, or priority avatar image by its ID. Key parameters include the `type` (issuetype, project, or priority), `id` of the avatar, `size` (e.g., small, medium, large), and `format` (PNG or SVG). This endpoint is useful when you need to display an avatar image in your application, such as for a project, issue type, or priority.
v2/AvatarsApi/getAvatarImageByOwner: The `getAvatarImageByOwner` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to retrieve the avatar image for a project, issue type, or priority. Key parameters include the `type` (issuetype, project, or priority), `entityId` (the ID of the project or issue type), `size` (to specify the desired image size), and `format` (to specify the desired image format). This endpoint can be used to access avatar images for various Jira entities, and the permissions required depend on the type of avatar being accessed.
v2/AvatarsApi/getAvatarImageByType: The `getAvatarImageByType` endpoint in the AvatarsApi retrieves the default project, issue type, or priority avatar image. It accepts parameters for the type of avatar, the size, and the image format, and can be accessed anonymously. This endpoint is useful when you need to display the default avatar images for these entities in your application.
v2/AvatarsApi/getAvatars: The `getAvatars` endpoint in the AvatarsApi retrieves the system and custom avatars for a given project, issue type, or priority. Key parameters are `type` (the avatar type) and `entityId` (the ID of the item the avatar is associated with). This endpoint can be used to fetch avatars for various Jira entities, and the permissions required depend on the avatar type being requested.
v2/AvatarsApi/storeAvatar: The `storeAvatar` endpoint in the AvatarsApi allows you to load a custom avatar for a project, issue type, or priority in Jira. It takes parameters such as the avatar type, entity ID, size, and optional crop coordinates. This endpoint is useful when you need to upload a custom avatar to be used in Jira, such as for a project, issue type, or priority.
v2/ClassificationLevelsApi/getAllUserDat: The `getAllUserDataClassificationLevels` endpoint in the ClassificationLevelsApi retrieves all available data classification levels. It supports optional filtering by status (PUBLISHED, ARCHIVED, DRAFT) and ordering by rank. This endpoint can be used to retrieve the list of available data classification levels for your application.
v2/DashboardsApi/addGadget: The `addGadget` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to add a new gadget to an existing dashboard. The only required parameter is the `dashboardId`, which specifies the ID of the dashboard to which the gadget will be added. You would use this endpoint to customize a dashboard by adding new widgets or tools to it.
v2/DashboardsApi/bulkEditDashboards: The `bulkEditDashboards` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to update multiple dashboards in a single request. The key parameter is the `BulkEditShareableEntityRequest`, which contains the details of the dashboards being updated. This endpoint is useful when you need to make the same changes to multiple dashboards, such as updating their permissions or other properties, and want to do so in a more efficient, batch-oriented manner.
v2/DashboardsApi/copyDashboard: The `copyDashboard` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to copy an existing dashboard. It takes in the `id` of the dashboard to be copied, the `DashboardDetails` object to replace values in the copied dashboard, and an optional `extendAdminPermissions` flag to use admin-level permissions. You would use this endpoint to create a new dashboard based on an existing one, with the ability to modify certain properties of the copied dashboard.
v2/DashboardsApi/createDashboard: The `createDashboard` endpoint in the Jira API is used to create a new dashboard. It requires the `DashboardDetails` object, which contains the details of the dashboard to be created. Additionally, the `extendAdminPermissions` parameter can be set to `true` if the user has the "Administer Jira" global permission, allowing them to create the dashboard. This endpoint would be used when you need to programmatically create a new dashboard in Jira.
v2/DashboardsApi/deleteDashboard: The `deleteDashboard` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to delete a specific dashboard by providing its `id`. This is useful when you need to remove a dashboard that is no longer needed or has been replaced. The request requires either OAuth2 or basic authentication, and the user making the request must be the owner of the dashboard being deleted.
v2/DashboardsApi/deleteDashboardItemProp: The `deleteDashboardItemProperty` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to delete a property of a dashboard item. This operation requires the user to have edit permission on the dashboard. You would use this endpoint when you need to remove a specific property associated with a dashboard item.
v2/DashboardsApi/getAllAvailableDashboar: The `getAllAvailableDashboardGadgets` endpoint retrieves a list of all available gadgets that can be added to dashboards. This endpoint requires no parameters and can be used by anyone with access to the Jira API, making it useful for fetching the list of available gadgets for dashboard customization.
v2/DashboardsApi/getAllDashboards: The `getAllDashboards` endpoint in the Jira API's DashboardsApi allows you to retrieve a list of dashboards owned by or shared with the user. You can filter the list to include only favorite or owned dashboards, and control the pagination of the results using the `startAt` and `maxResults` parameters. This endpoint can be accessed anonymously and is useful when you need to retrieve and display a user's dashboards in your application.
v2/DashboardsApi/getAllGadgets: The `getAllGadgets` endpoint in the DashboardsApi retrieves a list of dashboard gadgets based on various parameters, such as dashboard ID, module key, URI, or gadget ID. This operation can be used to retrieve all gadgets on a dashboard, gadgets with a specific module key, gadgets with a list of URIs, or gadgets with a list of IDs. The response is a `DashboardGadgetResponse` object, and the endpoint can be accessed anonymously.
v2/DashboardsApi/getDashboard: The `getDashboard` endpoint in the Jira API retrieves a specific dashboard using the dashboard ID. This endpoint can be accessed anonymously, but the dashboard must be shared with the user or owned by the user to retrieve it. The response returns a `Dashboard` object, which includes details about the dashboard.
v2/DashboardsApi/getDashboardItemPropert: The `getDashboardItemProperty` endpoint retrieves the key and value of a dashboard item property in Jira. This endpoint is used to access user-specific information stored in a dashboard item, such as the item's content or configuration details. You would use this endpoint when you need to retrieve the properties of a specific dashboard item in your application.

The `getDashboardItemPropertyKeys` endpoint in the Jira API returns the keys of all properties for a specific dashboard item. The required parameters are the `dashboardId` and `itemId`. This endpoint can be used to retrieve the property keys for a given dashboard item, which may be useful for understanding the available data or customizing the display of the item.
v2/DashboardsApi/getDashboardsPaginated: The `getDashboardsPaginated` endpoint from the Jira API's DashboardsApi allows you to search for and retrieve a paginated list of dashboards. You can filter the results by various attributes such as dashboard name, owner, group, project, and status. The response includes details about the dashboards, such as description, owner, view URL, and share/edit permissions, which can be controlled using the `expand` parameter. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve a subset of dashboards based on specific criteria, rather than getting all dashboards at once.
v2/DashboardsApi/removeGadget: The `removeGadget` endpoint in the DashboardsApi removes a specific gadget from a dashboard. It requires the `dashboardId` and `gadgetId` as parameters. This endpoint is useful when you need to remove a gadget from a dashboard, for example, to rearrange the layout or remove unused gadgets.
v2/DashboardsApi/setDashboardItemPropert: The `setDashboardItemProperty` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to set the value of a dashboard item property. This is useful for storing custom data associated with a dashboard item, such as its content or configuration details. You would use this endpoint when you need to update the properties of a dashboard item, for example, in a Jira Connect add-on that integrates with the dashboard. The key parameters are the `dashboardId`, `itemId`, and `propertyKey`, along with the JSON-formatted `body` containing the new property value.
v2/DashboardsApi/updateDashboard: The `updateDashboard` endpoint from the DashboardsApi updates a dashboard by replacing all its details with the provided `DashboardDetails`. This endpoint is used when you need to modify an existing dashboard, and you have the necessary permissions. The dashboard to be updated must be owned by the user making the request, unless the `extendAdminPermissions` parameter is set to `true`, which requires the user to have the "Administer Jira" global permission.
v2/DashboardsApi/updateGadget: The `updateGadget` endpoint in the DashboardsApi allows you to update the title, position, and color of a gadget on a dashboard. You would use this endpoint when you need to modify the appearance and placement of a gadget within a dashboard.
v2/DefaultApi/getWorklogsByIssueIdAndWor: This endpoint retrieves worklog details for a list of issue ID and worklog ID pairs. It is an internal API that requires ASAP authentication and no user permission checks are performed. The returned list of worklogs is limited to 1000 items. You would use this endpoint when you need to bulk fetch worklogs by their issue and worklog IDs.
v2/DynamicModulesApi/dynamicModulesResou: The `dynamicModulesResource.getModulesGet` endpoint retrieves all modules registered dynamically by the calling Connect app. This endpoint does not require any parameters and can be used to fetch the list of registered modules, which is returned as a `ConnectModules` object. This API is exclusive to Jira Connect apps.

The `dynamicModulesResource.registerModulesPost` endpoint allows you to register a list of modules in Jira. It's used by Connect apps and requires no authorization. The key parameter is the `ConnectModules` object, which contains the details of the modules to be registered.

The `dynamicModulesResource.removeModulesDelete` endpoint allows you to remove one or more modules registered by a Connect app. You can specify the module keys to remove using the `moduleKey` parameter. This endpoint is useful when you need to remove dynamic modules that were previously added to Jira.
v2/FilterSharingApi/addSharePermission: The `addSharePermission` endpoint in the FilterSharingApi allows you to add a share permission to a filter. It takes the filter ID and a `SharePermissionInputBean` object as parameters, and returns a list of `SharePermission` objects. This endpoint is useful when you need to grant access to a filter for specific users, groups, or the public.
v2/FilterSharingApi/deleteSharePermissio: The `deleteSharePermission` endpoint in the FilterSharingApi allows you to delete a share permission from a filter. It requires the filter ID and the permission ID as parameters, and the user must have permission to access Jira and own the filter. This endpoint is useful when you need to revoke sharing permissions on a filter.
v2/FilterSharingApi/getDefaultShareScope: The `getDefaultShareScope` endpoint retrieves the default sharing settings for new filters and dashboards for the user. This endpoint does not require any parameters and returns a `DefaultShareScope` object, which is useful when you need to determine the default sharing configuration for a user's Jira resources.
v2/FilterSharingApi/getSharePermission: The `getSharePermission` endpoint in the FilterSharingApi retrieves a specific share permission for a given filter. This is used to get information about how a filter has been shared, such as with specific groups, projects, or publicly. The key parameters are the `id` of the filter and the `permissionId` of the specific share permission to retrieve. You would use this endpoint to check the sharing configuration of a filter.
v2/FilterSharingApi/getSharePermissions: The `getSharePermissions` endpoint in the FilterSharingApi retrieves the share permissions for a given filter. It returns a list of `SharePermission` objects, which represent the groups, projects, or public access settings that the filter has been shared with. This endpoint can be used when you need to view the current sharing configuration for a filter, such as when managing filter access or permissions.
v2/FilterSharingApi/setDefaultShareScope: The `setDefaultShareScope` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to set the default sharing scope for new filters and dashboards for a user. The only required parameter is a `DefaultShareScope` object, which specifies the new default sharing scope. This endpoint would be used when you need to programmatically set the default sharing preferences for a Jira user.
v2/FiltersApi/changeFilterOwner: The `changeFilterOwner` endpoint in the FiltersApi allows you to change the owner of a Jira filter. The key parameter is the `id` of the filter to be updated and the `ChangeFilterOwner` object containing the new owner's account ID. You would use this endpoint when you need to transfer ownership of a filter to a different user.
v2/FiltersApi/createFilter: The `createFilter` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to create a new filter. Key parameters include `Filter` (the filter to create), `expand` (to include additional information like shared users and subscriptions), and `overrideSharePermissions` (to enable creating filters with any share permissions). This endpoint is used when you need to create a new custom filter in Jira.
v2/FiltersApi/deleteFavouriteForFilter: The `deleteFavouriteForFilter` endpoint in the FiltersApi of the Jira API allows you to remove a filter as a favorite for the user. This operation only removes filters that are visible to the user from their favorites list. You would use this endpoint when you need to remove a filter from a user's favorites list.
v2/FiltersApi/deleteFilter: The `deleteFilter` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to delete a filter. You would use this endpoint to remove a filter that you have created or if you have the "Administer Jira" global permission. The only required parameter is the `id` of the filter you want to delete.
v2/FiltersApi/getColumns: The `getColumns` endpoint in the FiltersApi retrieves the column configuration for a specified filter. This operation can be accessed anonymously, but the column details are only returned for filters the user has access to. Key parameters include the `id` of the filter. This endpoint would be used to fetch the column configuration of a filter, which is used when viewing the filter's results in List View.
v2/FiltersApi/getFavouriteFilters: The `getFavouriteFilters` endpoint in the Jira API returns the visible favorite filters of the user. Key parameters include `expand`, which can be used to include additional information about the filters, such as the users the filter is shared with and the users subscribed to the filter. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve the favorite filters for a user, for example, to display them in a user interface.
v2/FiltersApi/getFilter: The `getFilter` endpoint retrieves a Jira filter by its ID. Key parameters include `expand` to include additional information about the filter, and `overrideSharePermissions` to override share permissions and return filters with any share permissions. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve details about a specific Jira filter, such as the users it is shared with or the users subscribed to it.
v2/FiltersApi/getFiltersPaginated: The `getFiltersPaginated` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to search for and retrieve a paginated list of filters. You can search for filters based on various parameters such as filter name, account ID, owner, group name/ID, project ID, and filter ID. You can also sort the results and specify the number of results to return per page. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve a list of filters that match certain criteria, such as filters owned by a specific user or shared with a particular group or project.
v2/FiltersApi/getMyFilters: The `getMyFilters` endpoint in the Jira API's FiltersApi retrieves the filters owned by the user. It allows you to optionally include the user's favorite filters and expand the response to include additional information about the filters, such as the shared users and subscriptions. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve the list of filters that a specific user has access to or has marked as favorites.
v2/FiltersApi/resetColumns: The `resetColumns` endpoint in the FiltersApi allows you to reset the user's column configuration for a specific filter to the default. This is useful when you want to restore the default column layout for a filter. The only required parameter is the `id` of the filter. The endpoint can be accessed with either OAuth2 or basic authentication, and it returns an empty response body.
v2/FiltersApi/setColumns: The `setColumns` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to set the columns for a filter. You can specify the IDs of the fields to be used as columns, which must be navigable fields. This endpoint is useful when you need to customize the columns displayed in a filter, such as for a custom view or report.
v2/FiltersApi/setFavouriteForFilter: The `setFavouriteForFilter` endpoint in the FiltersApi allows you to add a filter as a favorite for the user. This is useful when you want to mark a specific filter as a favorite for easy access. The endpoint requires the filter ID as a parameter and supports optional expansion of shared users and subscriptions. You would use this endpoint when you want to designate a filter as a favorite for a user.
v2/FiltersApi/updateFilter: The `updateFilter` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to update an existing filter. Key parameters include the filter ID, the updated filter object, and optional parameters to expand the response with additional information like shared users and subscriptions. You would use this endpoint when you need to modify the details of an existing filter, such as its name, description, JQL, or sharing permissions.
v2/GroupAndUserPickerApi/findUsersAndGro: The `findUsersAndGroups` endpoint in the GroupAndUserPickerApi allows you to search for and return a list of users and groups that match a given query string. Key parameters include the ability to filter the results by project, issue type, avatar size, and case sensitivity. This endpoint is commonly used to populate a picker field suggestion list with users or groups.
v2/GroupsApi/addUserToGroup: The `addUserToGroup` endpoint in the Jira API is used to add a user to a group. Key parameters include the `UpdateUserToGroupBean` object, which specifies the user to be added, and either the `groupname` or `groupId` parameter to identify the group. This endpoint requires site administration permissions and would be used when needing to add a user to a specific group in Jira.
v2/GroupsApi/bulkGetGroups: The `bulkGetGroups` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to retrieve a paginated list of groups. You can filter the results by group ID, group name, access type, and application key. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve information about multiple groups at once, for example, to populate a search index.
v2/GroupsApi/createGroup: The `createGroup` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to create a new group. The only required parameter is the `AddGroupBean` object, which contains the name of the group to be created. This endpoint requires site administration permissions and would be used to add new groups to the Jira system.
v2/GroupsApi/findGroups: The `findGroups` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to search for groups whose names contain a specified query string. Key parameters include `query`, `exclude`, `excludeId`, and `maxResults`. This endpoint is commonly used to populate a group picker suggestions list, as it returns the matched groups with the query term highlighted in the group name.
v2/GroupsApi/getGroup: The `getGroup` endpoint in the Jira API's GroupsApi returns all users in a specified group. Key parameters include `groupname` and `groupId`, which can be used to identify the group, and `expand` to control the response fields. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve information about a group, such as its members, in Jira.
v2/GroupsApi/getUsersFromGroup: The `getUsersFromGroup` endpoint retrieves a paginated list of users in a specified group. Key parameters include `groupname` or `groupId` to identify the group, `includeInactiveUsers` to include inactive users, and `startAt` and `maxResults` to control pagination. This endpoint is useful for administrators who need to view and manage the users within a particular group in Jira.
v2/GroupsApi/removeGroup: The `removeGroup` endpoint in the GroupsApi allows you to delete a group in Jira. It requires either the `groupname` or `groupId` parameter to identify the group to be deleted. Optionally, you can specify a `swapGroup` or `swapGroupId` parameter to transfer any associated restrictions, comments, and worklogs to another group before deleting the original group. This endpoint is used when you need to remove a group from Jira, while ensuring that any associated data is preserved.
v2/GroupsApi/removeUserFromGroup: The `removeUserFromGroup` endpoint in the GroupsApi allows you to remove a user from a group in Jira. It requires the account ID of the user, the group name or ID, and the username of the user to be removed. This endpoint is useful when you need to revoke a user's membership in a specific group, and requires site administration permissions.
v2/IssueAttachmentsApi/addAttachment: The `addAttachment` endpoint in the IssueAttachmentsApi allows you to add one or more attachments to an issue in Jira. The request must be made with a `X-Atlassian-Token: no-check` header and the attachments must be sent as multipart/form-data with the `file` parameter. You would use this endpoint when you need to attach files to a Jira issue, such as when providing additional information or documentation related to the issue.
v2/IssueAttachmentsApi/expandAttachmentF: The `expandAttachmentForHumans` endpoint in the IssueAttachmentsApi retrieves the metadata for the contents of an attachment, if it is an archive (e.g., a ZIP file), along with metadata for the attachment itself. This operation is useful for retrieving data that is presented to the user, and it can be accessed anonymously if the user has the necessary permissions.

The `expandAttachmentForMachines` endpoint in the IssueAttachmentsApi retrieves the metadata for the contents of an attachment, if it is an archive (e.g., a ZIP file). This operation is useful when you need to process the data without presenting it to the user, as it only returns the metadata for the contents of the attachment, not the attachment itself. The endpoint requires the `Browse projects` project permission and possibly additional permissions depending on the attachment's visibility.
v2/IssueAttachmentsApi/getAttachment: The `getAttachment` endpoint in the IssueAttachmentsApi retrieves the metadata for a given attachment ID. This can be useful when you need to access information about an attachment, such as its file name or size, without downloading the attachment itself. The endpoint requires project-level and potentially issue-level or comment-level permissions to access the attachment metadata.
v2/IssueAttachmentsApi/getAttachmentCont: The `getAttachmentContent` endpoint in the IssueAttachmentsApi retrieves the contents of a specified attachment. It allows you to download the full attachment or a range of bytes within it, and can optionally provide a redirect to the attachment download. You would use this endpoint when you need to access the contents of an attachment associated with a Jira issue.
v2/IssueAttachmentsApi/getAttachmentMeta: The `getAttachmentMeta` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to retrieve the attachment settings, including whether attachments are enabled and the maximum attachment size allowed. This is a read-only operation that does not require any special permissions, and it can be accessed anonymously. You might use this endpoint to gather information about the attachment capabilities of a Jira instance before performing operations that involve attachments.
v2/IssueAttachmentsApi/getAttachmentThum: The `getAttachmentThumbnail` endpoint in the IssueAttachmentsApi returns the thumbnail of a Jira issue attachment. Key parameters include the attachment ID, whether to redirect, whether to use a default thumbnail, and the desired thumbnail dimensions. This endpoint would be used to retrieve the thumbnail of an attachment associated with a Jira issue.
v2/IssueAttachmentsApi/removeAttachment: The `removeAttachment` endpoint in the IssueAttachmentsApi allows you to delete an attachment from a Jira issue. The only required parameter is the `id` of the attachment to be deleted. This endpoint can be used to delete attachments that the calling user created or, with the appropriate permissions, attachments created by any user on the project.
v2/IssueCommentPropertiesApi/deleteComme: The `deleteCommentProperty` endpoint deletes a comment property, using the `commentId` and `propertyKey` parameters. It requires either the "Edit All Comments" or "Edit Own Comments" project permission, depending on the user's access level. This endpoint is useful for removing specific properties from a comment, such as custom metadata or annotations.
v2/IssueCommentPropertiesApi/getCommentP: The `getCommentProperty` endpoint retrieves the value of a specific property associated with a Jira issue comment. Key parameters are `commentId` and `propertyKey`. This endpoint can be used to access comment properties, such as metadata or custom fields, that are associated with a specific comment on a Jira issue.

The `getCommentPropertyKeys` endpoint retrieves the keys of all the properties of a comment in Jira. It requires the `commentId` parameter and the appropriate permissions to access the project and the comment. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve the metadata associated with a specific comment in Jira.
v2/IssueCommentPropertiesApi/setCommentP: The `setCommentProperty` endpoint in the IssueCommentPropertiesApi allows you to create or update the value of a property for a comment in Jira. The key parameters are `commentId`, `propertyKey`, and `body`, which represent the ID of the comment, the key of the property, and the value of the property (a valid JSON blob), respectively. This endpoint is useful for storing custom data against a comment in Jira.
v2/IssueCommentsApi/addComment: The `addComment` endpoint in the IssueCommentsApi allows you to add a comment to an issue in Jira. The key parameters are `issueIdOrKey` (the ID or key of the issue) and `Comment` (the comment object to be added). This endpoint is useful when you need to programmatically add comments to Jira issues, such as for automating workflows or integrating with other systems.
v2/IssueCommentsApi/deleteComment: The `deleteComment` endpoint in the IssueCommentsApi allows you to delete a comment from a Jira issue. It requires the `Browse projects` project permission, issue-level security permission to view the issue, and either the `Delete all comments` project permission or the `Delete own comments` permission if the comment has visibility restrictions. You would use this endpoint to remove a specific comment from an issue when needed.
v2/IssueCommentsApi/getComment: The `getComment` endpoint in the IssueCommentsApi retrieves a specific comment for a given issue. Key parameters include the `issueIdOrKey` to identify the issue, the `id` to specify the comment, and the optional `expand` parameter to include the rendered comment body. This endpoint can be useful when you need to retrieve detailed information about a specific comment on an issue.
v2/IssueCommentsApi/getComments: The `getComments` endpoint in the IssueCommentsApi returns all comments for a specified issue. Key parameters include `issueIdOrKey` to identify the issue, `startAt` and `maxResults` to control pagination, `orderBy` to sort the results, and `expand` to include additional comment details. This endpoint is useful for retrieving and displaying the comments associated with a specific issue.
v2/IssueCommentsApi/getCommentsByIds: The `getCommentsByIds` endpoint in the IssueCommentsApi retrieves a paginated list of comments specified by a list of comment IDs. You would use this endpoint when you need to retrieve specific comments by their IDs, and you can optionally expand the response to include additional information such as the rendered comment body and the comment's properties.
v2/IssueCommentsApi/updateComment: The `updateComment` endpoint of the IssueCommentsApi allows you to update an existing comment on a Jira issue. Key parameters include the issue ID or key, the comment ID, the new comment text, and optional flags to control user notification and override edit permissions. You would use this endpoint when you need to edit an existing comment on a Jira issue, for example to correct a typo or provide additional information.
v2/IssueCustomFieldAssociationsApi/creat: The `createAssociations` endpoint in the IssueCustomFieldAssociationsApi allows you to associate custom fields with projects in Jira. It takes a `FieldAssociationsRequest` object as input, which specifies the fields to associate and the projects to associate them with. This endpoint is useful when you need to programmatically manage the association of custom fields with projects in your Jira instance.
v2/IssueCustomFieldAssociationsApi/remov: The `removeAssociations` endpoint in the IssueCustomFieldAssociationsApi is used to unassociate a set of custom fields from a project and issue type context. It allows you to remove the association of up to 50 fields and up to 100 projects and issue types in a single request. This can be useful when you need to manage the field configurations across your Jira instance.
v2/IssueCustomFieldConfigurationAppsApi/: The `getCustomFieldConfiguration` endpoint in the IssueCustomFieldConfigurationAppsApi retrieves a paginated list of configurations for a custom field created by a Forge app. Key parameters include `fieldIdOrKey`, `id`, `fieldContextId`, `issueId`, `projectKeyOrId`, and `issueTypeId`, which can be used to filter the results. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve information about custom field configurations in your Jira instance.

This endpoint returns a paginated list of configurations for custom fields created by a Forge app. You can filter the results by the custom field ID, field context ID, issue ID, project, and issue type. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve information about the configurations of custom fields in your Jira instance, such as when building a search index or application that interacts with custom fields.

The `updateCustomFieldConfiguration` endpoint in the `IssueCustomFieldConfigurationAppsApi` allows you to update the configuration for contexts of a custom field created by a Forge app. It takes the `fieldIdOrKey` parameter to identify the custom field and a `CustomFieldConfigurations` object to provide the updated configuration. This endpoint is useful when you need to modify the settings or behavior of a custom field in Jira, and you have the necessary permissions to do so.
v2/IssueCustomFieldContextsApi/addIssueT: This endpoint allows you to add issue types to a custom field context in Jira. The key parameters are the `fieldId`, `contextId`, and `IssueTypeIds`. You would use this endpoint when you need to associate specific issue types with a custom field context, such as when you want to limit the availability of a custom field to certain issue types.
v2/IssueCustomFieldContextsApi/assignPro: The `assignProjectsToCustomFieldContext` endpoint in the IssueCustomFieldContextsApi allows you to assign a custom field context to projects. It takes the custom field ID, context ID, and a list of project IDs as input parameters. This endpoint is useful when you need to associate a custom field with specific projects in your Jira instance. The operation requires the "Administer Jira" global permission.
v2/IssueCustomFieldContextsApi/createCus: This endpoint allows you to create a custom field context in Jira. It requires the `fieldId` parameter to specify the custom field and accepts a `CreateCustomFieldContext` object as the request body. This endpoint is used to create a global context, which applies to all projects and issue types, or a context that applies to specific project IDs and issue type IDs. You would use this endpoint when you need to set up a new custom field context in your Jira instance.
v2/IssueCustomFieldContextsApi/deleteCus: The `deleteCustomFieldContext` endpoint in the IssueCustomFieldContextsApi allows you to delete a custom field context in Jira. It requires the `fieldId` and `contextId` parameters, and the `Administer Jira` global permission. This endpoint is useful when you need to remove a custom field context that is no longer needed or applicable.
v2/IssueCustomFieldContextsApi/getContex: The `getContextsForField` endpoint in the IssueCustomFieldContextsApi retrieves a paginated list of custom field contexts for a specific custom field. You can filter the results by issue type, global context, and context ID. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve information about the contexts associated with a custom field, such as for managing or displaying custom field configurations.
v2/IssueCustomFieldContextsApi/getCustom: The `getCustomFieldContextsForProjectsAndIssueTypes` endpoint in the IssueCustomFieldContextsApi returns a paginated list of project and issue type mappings, along with the ID of the custom field context that applies to each mapping. It is used to retrieve information about the custom field contexts associated with specific projects and issue types.
v2/IssueCustomFieldContextsApi/getDefaul: The `getDefaultValues` endpoint in the IssueCustomFieldContextsApi allows you to retrieve the default values for a custom field. It supports various custom field types and returns a paginated list of default values, which can be filtered by the `contextId` parameter. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve the default values for a custom field, for example, to display or modify them in a custom application.
v2/IssueCustomFieldContextsApi/getIssueT: This endpoint retrieves a paginated list of issue type to custom field context mappings for a given custom field. Key parameters include the custom field ID, context ID(s), start index, and maximum number of results to return. This endpoint is useful for administrators to manage the issue type to custom field context mappings for a particular custom field.
v2/IssueCustomFieldContextsApi/getProjec: The `getProjectContextMapping` endpoint in the IssueCustomFieldContextsApi retrieves a paginated list of project mappings for a custom field context. It allows you to filter the results by the `contextId` parameter and supports pagination via `startAt` and `maxResults` parameters. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve information about the project-context mappings for a custom field.
v2/IssueCustomFieldContextsApi/removeCus: The `removeCustomFieldContextFromProjects` endpoint in the IssueCustomFieldContextsApi allows you to remove a custom field context from specified projects. It takes in the `fieldId`, `contextId`, and a list of `ProjectIds` as parameters. This endpoint is useful when you need to remove a custom field context from one or more projects, for example, when reorganizing your project structure or updating custom field configurations.
v2/IssueCustomFieldContextsApi/removeIss: The `removeIssueTypesFromContext` endpoint in the IssueCustomFieldContextsApi removes issue types from a custom field context in Jira. It requires the `fieldId`, `contextId`, and a list of `IssueTypeIds` to be provided. This endpoint is useful when you need to remove specific issue types from a custom field context, for example, when you want to change the applicability of a custom field.
v2/IssueCustomFieldContextsApi/setDefaul: The `setDefaultValues` endpoint in the IssueCustomFieldContextsApi allows you to set the default values for the contexts of a custom field in Jira. You can provide different types of default values based on the custom field type, such as date, option, user, or group. This endpoint is useful when you need to configure the default values for custom fields across different contexts in Jira. To use this endpoint, you need the "Administer Jira" global permission.
v2/IssueCustomFieldContextsApi/updateCus: The `updateCustomFieldContext` endpoint in the IssueCustomFieldContextsApi updates a custom field context in Jira. It requires the `fieldId`, `contextId`, and a `CustomFieldContextUpdateDetails` object as parameters. This endpoint is used when you need to modify the settings or configuration of a custom field context, such as changing the project associations or field behavior.
v2/IssueCustomFieldOptionsApi/createCust: The `createCustomFieldOption` endpoint in the IssueCustomFieldOptionsApi allows you to create custom field options, including cascading options, for a specific custom select field in a given context. You would use this endpoint when you need to add new options to a custom field, such as when managing the available options for a custom issue field. v2/IssueCustomFieldOptionsApi/deleteCust: The `deleteCustomFieldOption` endpoint in the IssueCustomFieldOptionsApi allows you to delete a custom field option from a specific context in Jira. You would use this endpoint when you need to remove an existing custom field option, such as when it is no longer needed or when you need to delete cascading options before deleting the main option. v2/IssueCustomFieldOptionsApi/getCustomF: The `getCustomFieldOption` endpoint in the IssueCustomFieldOptionsApi retrieves a custom field option, such as an option in a select list, in Jira. This operation requires the user to have either the "Administer Jira" global permission or the "Browse projects" project permission for at least one project where the custom field is used. v2/IssueCustomFieldOptionsApi/getOptions: The `getOptionsForContext` endpoint in the IssueCustomFieldOptionsApi retrieves a paginated list of custom field options for a specific context. It allows you to filter the results by custom field ID, context ID, option ID, and pagination parameters. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve and manage the custom field options associated with a particular context, such as when working with custom field select lists in Jira.
v2/IssueCustomFieldOptionsApi/reorderCus: The `reorderCustomFieldOptions` endpoint in the IssueCustomFieldOptionsApi allows you to change the order of custom field options or cascading options in a specific context. It requires the `fieldId`, `contextId`, and an `OrderOfCustomFieldOptions` object as parameters. This endpoint is typically used when you need to reorder the options for a custom field within a given context, and you have the necessary permissions to perform this administrative action.
v2/IssueCustomFieldOptionsApi/replaceCus: The `replaceCustomFieldOption` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to replace the options of a custom field. This is useful when you need to update or change the available options for a custom field, but it can only be used with issue field select list options created in Jira, not those created by Connect or Forge apps. You'll need the "Administer Jira" global permission to use this endpoint.
v2/IssueCustomFieldOptionsApi/updateCust: The `updateCustomFieldOption` endpoint in the `IssueCustomFieldOptionsApi` allows you to update the options of a custom field in Jira. You can specify the field ID and context ID, and provide a `BulkCustomFieldOptionUpdateRequest` to update the options. This endpoint is useful when you need to manage the options for a custom field in Jira, such as adding, modifying, or removing options.
v2/IssueCustomFieldOptionsAppsApi/create: The `createIssueFieldOption` endpoint in the IssueCustomFieldOptionsAppsApi allows you to create an option for a select list issue field that was added by a Connect app. This is useful when you need to manage the options for a custom field in your app. The key parameters are the `fieldKey`, which identifies the custom field, and the `IssueFieldOptionCreateBean` that contains the details of the new option to be created. v2/IssueCustomFieldOptionsAppsApi/delete: This endpoint deletes an option from a select list issue field in Jira, specifically for options added by Connect apps. v2/IssueCustomFieldOptionsAppsApi/getAll: The `getAllIssueFieldOptions` endpoint in the `IssueCustomFieldOptionsAppsApi` returns a paginated list of all the options of a select list issue field created by Jira Connect apps. v2/IssueCustomFieldOptionsAppsApi/getIss: The `getIssueFieldOption` endpoint in the IssueCustomFieldOptionsAppsApi allows you to retrieve a specific option from a select list issue field created by a Connect app. This is useful when you need to access information about custom field options that were added by a third-party app, rather than those created within Jira. The endpoint requires the `fieldKey` (in a specific format) and the `optionId` as parameters.
v2/IssueCustomFieldOptionsAppsApi/getSel: The `getSelectableIssueFieldOptions` endpoint in the IssueCustomFieldOptionsAppsApi retrieves a paginated list of selectable options for a custom issue field added by a Connect app. Key parameters include the `fieldKey` to identify the field, `startAt` and `maxResults` for pagination, and `projectId` to filter by project. v2/IssueCustomFieldOptionsAppsApi/getVis: The `getVisibleIssueFieldOptions` endpoint in the `IssueCustomFieldOptionsAppsApi` retrieves a paginated list of options for a select list issue field that can be viewed by the user. This endpoint is specifically for issue field select list options added by Connect apps, not those created in Jira or using other operations. v2/IssueCustomFieldOptionsAppsApi/replac: The `replaceIssueFieldOption` endpoint in the IssueCustomFieldOptionsAppsApi allows you to replace an issue-field select-list option with a different option across all issues where the original option is selected. You can use this endpoint to update issue fields added by Connect apps, and you can optionally limit the update to a set of issues using a JQL query. This is an asynchronous operation, and the response contains a link to the long-running task.
v2/IssueCustomFieldOptionsAppsApi/update: The `updateIssueFieldOption` endpoint in the IssueCustomFieldOptionsAppsApi is used to update or create an option for a select list issue field. It requires the `fieldKey` and `optionId` parameters, and takes an `IssueFieldOption` object in the request body. This endpoint is specifically for issue field select list options added by Connect apps, and can't be used for options created in Jira or using other operations from the Issue custom field options resource. v2/IssueCustomFieldValuesAppsApi/updateC: The `updateCustomFieldValue` endpoint in the IssueCustomFieldValuesAppsApi allows you to update the value of a custom field on one or more issues. This endpoint is useful when you need to programmatically update the value of a custom field in your Jira application.
v2/IssueCustomFieldValuesAppsApi/updateM: This endpoint updates the values of one or more custom fields on one or more issues. The key parameters are `MultipleCustomFieldValuesUpdateDetails`, which contains the details of the updates, and `generateChangelog`, which determines whether to generate a changelog for the update. v2/IssueFieldConfigurationsApi/assignFie: The `assignFieldConfigurationSchemeToProject` endpoint in the IssueFieldConfigurationsApi allows you to assign a field configuration scheme to a project. This endpoint is useful when you need to configure the fields and their behavior for a specific project in your Jira instance.
v2/IssueFieldConfigurationsApi/createFie: The `createFieldConfiguration` endpoint in the IssueFieldConfigurationsApi creates a new field configuration in Jira. The key parameter is `FieldConfigurationDetails`, which provides the details of the new configuration. This endpoint is used when you need to create a custom field configuration, typically for company-managed (classic) projects, and requires the 'Administer Jira' global permission.

The `createFieldConfigurationScheme` endpoint in the IssueFieldConfigurationsApi creates a new field configuration scheme in Jira. It takes an `UpdateFieldConfigurationSchemeDetails` object as a parameter, which contains the details of the new scheme. This endpoint is useful when you need to set up a custom field configuration scheme for company-managed (classic) projects, and requires the "Administer Jira" global permission.
v2/IssueFieldConfigurationsApi/deleteFie: The `deleteFieldConfiguration` endpoint in the IssueFieldConfigurationsApi allows you to delete a field configuration in Jira. The `deleteFieldConfigurationScheme` endpoint in the IssueFieldConfigurationsApi deletes a field configuration scheme used in company-managed (classic) Jira projects. It requires the "Administer Jira" global permission and takes the `id` of the field configuration scheme as a parameter.
v2/IssueFieldConfigurationsApi/getAllFie: The `getAllFieldConfigurationSchemes` endpoint in the IssueFieldConfigurationsApi retrieves a paginated list of all field configuration schemes used in classic Jira projects. v2/IssueFieldConfigurationsApi/getFieldC: The `getFieldConfigurationItems` endpoint in the IssueFieldConfigurationsApi retrieves a paginated list of all fields for a specific field configuration. Key parameters include the `id` of the field configuration, `startAt` for pagination, and `maxResults` to control the number of items returned per page.

The `getFieldConfigurationSchemeMappings` endpoint returns a paginated list of field configuration issue type items used in classic Jira projects. It requires the "Administer Jira" global permission, and allows you to filter the results by one or more field configuration scheme IDs.

v2/IssueFieldConfigurationsApi/removeIss: The `removeIssueTypesFromGlobalFieldConfigurationScheme` endpoint in the IssueFieldConfigurationsApi allows you to remove issue types from a field configuration scheme. v2/IssueFieldConfigurationsApi/setFieldC: The `setFieldConfigurationSchemeMapping` endpoint in the IssueFieldConfigurationsApi allows you to assign issue types to field configurations on a field configuration scheme. v2/IssueFieldConfigurationsApi/updateFie: The `updateFieldConfiguration` endpoint of the IssueFieldConfigurationsApi allows you to update a field configuration in Jira. v2/IssueFieldsApi/createCustomField: The `createCustomField` endpoint in the IssueFieldsApi allows you to create a custom field in Jira. v2/IssueFieldsApi/deleteCustomField: The `deleteCustomField` endpoint in the Jira API deletes a custom field, regardless of whether it is in the trash or not. v2/IssueFieldsApi/getContextsForFieldDep: The `getContextsForFieldDeprecated` endpoint in the IssueFieldsApi retrieves a paginated list of the contexts a field is used in. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve information about the contexts a custom field is used in, which can be helpful for administrative tasks or understanding field usage within your Jira instance.
v2/IssueFieldsApi/getFields: The `getFields` endpoint in the IssueFieldsApi retrieves a list of system and custom issue fields, including fields that cannot be added to the issue navigator, placed on an issue screen, or depend on global Jira settings. This endpoint can be accessed anonymously and does not require any parameters. It's useful when you need to retrieve information about the available issue fields in a Jira instance.
v2/IssueFieldsApi/getFieldsPaginated: The `getFieldsPaginated` endpoint in the IssueFieldsApi retrieves a paginated list of fields for Classic Jira projects. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve and manage information about Jira fields, such as custom fields or system fields, for various use cases like reporting or field configuration.
v2/IssueFieldsApi/getTrashedFieldsPagina: The `getTrashedFieldsPaginated` endpoint in the IssueFieldsApi allows you to retrieve a paginated list of custom fields that have been moved to the trash in Jira. You can filter the results by field ID, name/description, and order the results by field name, trash date, or planned deletion date. This endpoint is useful when managing custom fields in Jira, such as when you need to view and potentially restore or permanently delete fields that have been trashed.
v2/IssueFieldsApi/restoreCustomField: The `restoreCustomField` endpoint in the IssueFieldsApi is used to restore a custom field from the trash in Jira. It requires the `id` parameter to identify the custom field to be restored, and the `Administer Jira` global permission. This endpoint would be used when a custom field has been previously deleted or trashed and needs to be brought back into use.
v2/IssueFieldsApi/trashCustomField: The `trashCustomField` endpoint in the IssueFieldsApi allows you to move a custom field to the trash in Jira. v2/IssueFieldsApi/updateCustomField: The `updateCustomField` endpoint in the IssueFieldsApi updates a custom field in Jira. This API is used when you need to modify the configuration of a custom field in Jira, and it requires the "Administer Jira" global permission.
v2/IssueLinkTypesApi/createIssueLinkType: The `createIssueLinkType` endpoint in the IssueLinkTypesApi allows you to create a new issue link type in Jira. v2/IssueLinkTypesApi/deleteIssueLinkType: The `deleteIssueLinkType` endpoint in the IssueLinkTypesApi allows you to delete an issue link type in Jira. This is useful when you need to remove a specific issue link type from your Jira instance. The operation requires the `Administer Jira` global permission.
v2/IssueLinkTypesApi/getIssueLinkType: The `getIssueLinkType` endpoint retrieves a specific issue link type by its ID. v2/IssueLinkTypesApi/getIssueLinkTypes: The `getIssueLinkTypes` endpoint in the IssueLinkTypesApi retrieves a list of all issue link types in the Jira instance. This endpoint can be used to access the available issue link types, which is useful when managing issue relationships. The endpoint requires the "Browse projects" project permission.
v2/IssueLinkTypesApi/updateIssueLinkType: The `updateIssueLinkType` endpoint in the IssueLinkTypesApi is used to update an existing issue link type in Jira. This endpoint is useful when you need to modify the configuration of an issue link type, such as its name or description, and requires the "Administer Jira" global permission.
v2/IssueLinksApi/deleteIssueLink: The `deleteIssueLink` endpoint in the IssueLinksApi allows you to delete an existing issue link by specifying the `linkId`. This operation requires the "Browse project" and "Link issues" project permissions for at least one of the projects containing the issues in the link, as well as permission to view both issues if issue-level security is configured.
v2/IssueLinksApi/getIssueLink: The `getIssueLink` endpoint in the IssueLinksApi retrieves a specific issue link by its ID. It requires the "Browse project" permission for all projects containing the linked issues, and if issue-level security is configured, permission to view both of the linked issues. This endpoint can be used to retrieve details about a specific issue link, such as its type and direction.
v2/IssueLinksApi/linkIssues: The `linkIssues` endpoint in the IssueLinksApi allows you to create a link between two issues in Jira. The key parameters include the `LinkIssueRequestJsonBean` which specifies the details of the link, such as the from and to issue keys, and an optional comment. This endpoint is useful when you need to indicate a relationship between two issues in your Jira instance, such as when one issue is a blocker for another.
v2/IssueNavigatorSettingsApi/getIssueNav: The `getIssueNavigatorDefaultColumns` endpoint in the IssueNavigatorSettingsApi retrieves the default issue navigator columns in Jira. This endpoint requires the "Administer Jira" global permission and can be used to retrieve the default configuration of the issue navigator view.
v2/IssueNavigatorSettingsApi/setIssueNav: The `setIssueNavigatorDefaultColumns` endpoint in the IssueNavigatorSettingsApi allows you to set the default issue navigator columns. This endpoint is useful when you need to customize the default columns displayed in the issue navigator.
v2/IssueNotificationSchemesApi/addNotifi: The `addNotifications` endpoint in the IssueNotificationSchemesApi allows you to add notifications to a notification scheme in Jira. This endpoint is useful when you need to configure the notification settings for a Jira project, such as specifying who should be notified when an issue is created or updated.
v2/IssueNotificationSchemesApi/createNot: The `createNotificationScheme` endpoint in the IssueNotificationSchemesApi allows you to create a new notification scheme in Jira, including up to 1000 notifications per request. You would use this endpoint when you need to set up custom notification rules for issues in your Jira instance, such as when certain events occur or specific conditions are met.
v2/IssueNotificationSchemesApi/deleteNot: The `deleteNotificationScheme` endpoint in the IssueNotificationSchemesApi deletes a notification scheme in Jira.
