The key parameters are the `id` of the workflow scheme and the `issueType` ID, along with an optional `returnDraftIfExists` flag to retrieve the mapping from the workflow scheme's draft instead of the published scheme.
v2/WorkflowSchemesApi/readWorkflowScheme: The `readWorkflowSchemes` endpoint in the WorkflowSchemesApi allows you to bulk retrieve workflow schemes by providing workflow scheme IDs or project IDs. You would use this endpoint when you need to access a list of workflow schemes, either globally or within specific projects, and you have the necessary permissions to do so.
v2/WorkflowSchemesApi/setWorkflowSchemeI: The `setWorkflowSchemeIssueType` endpoint in the Jira API is used to set the workflow for an issue type in a workflow scheme. This is useful when you need to associate a specific workflow with an issue type within a workflow scheme. The key parameters are the workflow scheme ID, the issue type ID, and the new issue type-workflow mapping. This endpoint is typically used when you need to configure or update the workflow associated with an issue type in a Jira project.
v2/WorkflowSchemesApi/updateDefaultWorkf: This endpoint updates the default workflow for a workflow scheme in Jira. It requires the ID of the workflow scheme and a new `DefaultWorkflow` object containing the details of the new default workflow. This is useful when you need to change the default workflow for a workflow scheme, particularly when the workflow scheme is active, as it can create or update a draft workflow scheme to make the change. This endpoint requires the "Administer Jira" global permission.
v2/WorkflowSchemesApi/updateSchemes: The `updateSchemes` endpoint of the WorkflowSchemesApi allows you to update company-managed and team-managed project workflow schemes. It supports updating the available statuses for issue types, triggering an asynchronous task to migrate the issues as defined in the provided mappings. This endpoint requires either the *Administer Jira* project permission to update all workflow schemes, or the *Administer projects* project permission to update project-scoped workflow schemes.
v2/WorkflowSchemesApi/updateWorkflowMapp: The `updateWorkflowMapping` endpoint in the WorkflowSchemesApi allows you to set the issue types for a workflow in a workflow scheme. It can also set the workflow as the default for the scheme. This endpoint is useful when you need to update the workflow-issue type mappings for a workflow scheme, especially for active schemes where you can create or update a draft scheme instead.
v2/WorkflowSchemesApi/updateWorkflowSche: The `updateWorkflowScheme` endpoint in the WorkflowSchemesApi allows you to update a company-managed project workflow scheme, including the name, default workflow, issue type to project mappings, and more. You would use this endpoint when you need to modify an existing workflow scheme, especially if it is currently being used by at least one project, in which case a draft workflow scheme is created or updated instead.
v2/WorkflowStatusCategoriesApi/getStatus: The `getStatusCategories` endpoint returns a list of all status categories in Jira, which can be used to retrieve information about the various workflow statuses within the system. This endpoint requires permission to access Jira and can be used with either OAuth2 or basic authentication.

The `getStatusCategory` endpoint in the WorkflowStatusCategoriesApi retrieves a status category, which provides a mechanism for categorizing statuses in Jira. You would use this endpoint when you need to get information about a specific status category, identified by its ID or key. The only required parameter is the `idOrKey` which specifies the ID or key of the status category you want to retrieve.
v2/WorkflowStatusesApi/getStatus: The `getStatus` endpoint in the WorkflowStatusesApi retrieves the details of a specific workflow status, identified by its ID or name. It requires the "Browse projects" project permission and can be accessed anonymously. This endpoint is useful when you need to obtain information about a specific workflow status, such as when working with Jira workflows or automating workflows.
v2/WorkflowStatusesApi/getStatuses: The `getStatuses` endpoint in the WorkflowStatusesApi retrieves a list of all statuses associated with active workflows. This operation can be accessed anonymously and requires the 'Browse projects' project permission. The returned data is a list of `StatusDetails` objects.
v2/WorkflowTransitionPropertiesApi/creat: The `createWorkflowTransitionProperty` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to add a new property to a workflow transition. Transition properties are used to customize the behavior of a workflow transition. You would use this endpoint when you need to modify the behavior of a specific workflow transition in your Jira instance. The key parameters are `transitionId`, `key`, `workflowName`, and `WorkflowTransitionProperty`, which define the transition, property key, workflow name, and the property itself. This endpoint requires the 'Administer Jira' global permission.
v2/WorkflowTransitionPropertiesApi/delet: This endpoint/model allows you to delete a workflow transition property. Transition properties are used to change the behavior of a workflow transition. You would use this endpoint when you need to remove a specific property from a workflow transition. The key parameters are the `transitionId`, `key`, `workflowName`, and optional `workflowMode` (either `live` or `draft`). This endpoint will be deprecated on June 1, 2026, and you should use the "Bulk update workflows" endpoint instead.
v2/WorkflowTransitionPropertiesApi/getWo: The `getWorkflowTransitionProperties` endpoint retrieves the properties of a workflow transition, which are used to change the behavior of the transition. Key parameters include the transition ID, workflow name, and optional parameters to filter the returned properties. This endpoint is typically used by Jira administrators to manage workflow configurations.
v2/WorkflowTransitionPropertiesApi/updat: The `updateWorkflowTransitionProperty` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to update a workflow transition property, which is used to change the behavior of a transition. Key parameters include the `transitionId`, `key` (the property name), `workflowName`, and the updated `WorkflowTransitionProperty` object. This endpoint is primarily used to modify existing transition properties or add new ones, and requires the "Administer Jira" global permission.
v2/WorkflowTransitionRulesApi/deleteWork: The `deleteWorkflowTransitionRuleConfigurations` endpoint allows Connect apps to delete workflow transition rules, such as post functions, conditions, and validators, from one or more workflows. This endpoint is used when you need to remove workflow transition rules created by your Connect app.
v2/WorkflowTransitionRulesApi/getWorkflo: The `getWorkflowTransitionRuleConfigurations` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to retrieve a paginated list of workflows with transition rules. You can filter the results by the type of transition rule, rule keys, workflow names, tags, and whether to include draft or published workflows. This endpoint is primarily used by Connect or Forge apps to access workflow transition rules created by the app.
v2/WorkflowTransitionRulesApi/updateWork: The `updateWorkflowTransitionRuleConfigurations` endpoint in the WorkflowTransitionRulesApi updates the configuration of workflow transition rules, including post functions, conditions, and validators. It can be used to disable rules or add tags for app migration purposes, and is only accessible to Connect or Forge apps. The endpoint takes a `WorkflowTransitionRulesUpdate` object as a parameter and returns a `WorkflowTransitionRulesUpdateErrors` object.
v2/WorkflowsApi/createWorkflow:
This endpoint/model allows you to create a new workflow in Jira. Key parameters or properties include:

- Defining transition rules using various condition types (e.g., always false, block transition until approval, compare number custom field, hide from user, only assignee, only reporter, permission, previous status, separation of duties, subtask blocking, user in any group, user in any project role, user in custom field, user in group).
- These conditions govern whether a transition can execute.

You'd use this endpoint when you need to create a new custom workflow in Jira, with specific transition rules and conditions tailored to your organization's needs.
v2/WorkflowsApi/createWorkflows: The `createWorkflows` endpoint in the WorkflowsApi allows you to bulk create workflows and their related statuses. The key parameter is the `WorkflowCreateRequest` object, which contains the details of the workflows to be created. This endpoint is useful when you need to create multiple workflows at once, and you require the appropriate permissions (`Administer Jira` or `Administer projects`) to do so.
v2/WorkflowsApi/deleteInactiveWorkflow: The `deleteInactiveWorkflow` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to delete an inactive workflow. It requires the `entityId` parameter to specify the workflow to delete. This endpoint is useful when you need to remove unused or outdated workflows from your Jira instance, but it has some restrictions - the workflow cannot be active, a system workflow, or associated with any workflow schemes.
v2/WorkflowsApi/getAllWorkflows: The `getAllWorkflows` endpoint in the Jira API is used to retrieve all workflows or a specific workflow by name. It requires the "Administer Jira" global permission and will be deprecated on February 1, 2026, so it is recommended to use the "Search workflows" endpoint instead. The main parameter is `workflowName`, which allows you to fetch a specific workflow, otherwise, an array of workflow objects is returned.
v2/WorkflowsApi/getDefaultEditor: The `getDefaultEditor` endpoint in the WorkflowsApi retrieves the user's default workflow editor, which can be either the new editor or the legacy editor. This endpoint does not require any parameters and returns a `DefaultWorkflowEditorResponse` object. It is commonly used to determine the user's preferred workflow editor.
v2/WorkflowsApi/getProjectUsagesForWorkf: The `getProjectUsagesForWorkflow` endpoint in the Jira API retrieves a paginated list of projects using a specific workflow. Key parameters include the `workflowId` to identify the workflow, `nextPageToken` to navigate through pages, and `maxResults` to control the number of results returned. This endpoint would be used to understand which projects are utilizing a particular workflow.
v2/WorkflowsApi/getWorkflowProjectIssueT: The `getWorkflowProjectIssueTypeUsages` endpoint retrieves the issue types in a project that are using a given workflow. It takes parameters such as the workflow ID, project ID, pagination cursor, and maximum results, and returns a paginated response of `WorkflowProjectIssueTypeUsageDTO` objects. This endpoint would be used to understand which issue types in a project are associated with a specific workflow.
v2/WorkflowsApi/getWorkflowSchemeUsagesF: The `getWorkflowSchemeUsagesForWorkflow` endpoint retrieves a paginated list of workflow schemes that are using a given workflow, with optional parameters to control the page size and cursor. This endpoint can be useful when you need to understand which workflow schemes are dependent on a particular workflow.
v2/WorkflowsApi/getWorkflowsPaginated: The `getWorkflowsPaginated` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to retrieve a paginated list of published classic workflows. You can filter the results by workflow name, expand additional information (e.g., transitions, statuses), and sort the results. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve and manage the workflows configured in your Jira instance, but it will be deprecated on June 1, 2026, so you should use the `Search workflows` endpoint instead.
v2/WorkflowsApi/readWorkflowPreviews: The `readWorkflowPreviews` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to preview a workflow within a given project. It returns a read-only preview of the workflow, omitting full configuration details. This endpoint requires either the "Administer projects" or "View (read-only) workflow" project permissions.
v2/WorkflowsApi/readWorkflows: The `readWorkflows` endpoint in the Jira API's `WorkflowsApi` allows you to retrieve a list of workflows and their related statuses. You can specify the workflows by name, ID, or by project and issue type. This endpoint is useful when you need to access workflow information, such as for administration or reporting purposes, and requires either the 'Administer Jira' global permission or the 'Administer projects' and 'View (read-only) workflow' project permissions.
v2/WorkflowsApi/searchWorkflows: The `searchWorkflows` endpoint in the Jira API is used to search for and retrieve a paginated list of global and project workflows. Key parameters include `queryString` to search by workflow name, `orderBy` to sort the results, `scope` to filter by project or global workflows, and `isActive` to filter by active/inactive workflows. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve information about the workflows configured in your Jira instance.
v2/WorkflowsApi/updateWorkflows: The `updateWorkflows` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to bulk update workflows and related statuses. It requires the `Administer Jira` project permission to create global-scoped workflows, or the `Administer projects` permission to create project-scoped workflows. You would use this endpoint when you need to update multiple workflows at once, rather than updating them individually.
v2/WorkflowsApi/validateCreateWorkflows: The `validateCreateWorkflows` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to validate the payload for bulk creating workflows. It takes a `WorkflowCreateValidateRequest` object as a parameter and returns a `WorkflowValidationErrorList` object, which contains information about any validation errors. This endpoint is useful when you need to create or update workflows in Jira, as it allows you to check the validity of your request before submitting it.
v2/WorkflowsApi/validateUpdateWorkflows: The `validateUpdateWorkflows` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to validate the payload for a bulk update of workflows. It takes a `WorkflowUpdateValidateRequestBean` object as a parameter and returns a `WorkflowValidationErrorList` object, which contains any validation errors. This endpoint is useful when you need to ensure the validity of a workflow update before applying it.
v2/WorkflowsApi/workflowCapabilities: The `workflowCapabilities` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to get the available workflow capabilities for a specific workflow, either by specifying the workflow ID or the project and issue type ID pair. The response includes details about the workflow's scope (global or project-based), the project types it is scoped to, and a list of all the workflow rules (conditions, validators, actions, triggers, and screens) along with their source (Atlassian-provided, Connect, or Forge). You would use this endpoint to retrieve information about a workflow's capabilities, which is useful for understanding and managing workflows in Jira.
v3/AnnouncementBannerApi/getBanner: The `getBanner` endpoint retrieves the current announcement banner configuration in Jira. It requires the "Administer Jira" global permission. You would use this endpoint to fetch the existing announcement banner settings, which can be helpful for managing or updating the banner.
v3/AnnouncementBannerApi/setBanner: The `setBanner` endpoint in the AnnouncementBannerApi updates the announcement banner configuration in Jira. It requires the "Administer Jira" global permission and takes an `AnnouncementBannerConfigurationUpdate` object as a parameter. This endpoint is used to modify the announcement banner displayed to Jira users.
v3/AppDataPoliciesApi/getPolicies: The `getPolicies` endpoint in the `AppDataPoliciesApi` retrieves the data policies for the specified project IDs. This can be useful when you need to understand the data policies associated with particular projects in your Jira instance. The endpoint accepts a comma-separated list of project IDs as input and returns the `ProjectDataPolicies` object, which contains the relevant policy information.
v3/AppDataPoliciesApi/getPolicy: The `getPolicy` endpoint in the `AppDataPoliciesApi` retrieves the data policy for the current workspace. This endpoint does not require any parameters and returns a `WorkspaceDataPolicy` object, which is used to manage the data policy settings for the workspace.
v3/AppMigrationApi/appIssueFieldValueUpd: The `appIssueFieldValueUpdateResource.updateIssueFieldsPut` endpoint is used to bulk update the values of custom fields added by Connect apps on one or more issues. It requires the `Atlassian-Transfer-Id` header and a `ConnectCustomFieldValues` object as the request body, which can update up to 200 custom fields. This endpoint is intended for use by Connect apps that need to update custom field values programmatically.
v3/AppMigrationApi/migrationResource.upd: This endpoint allows you to bulk update the values of multiple entity properties for an object, up to 50 updates per request. It's used by Connect apps during app migration when the `Atlassian-Transfer-Id` and `entityType` parameters are provided, along with a list of `EntityPropertyDetails` to update.
v3/AppMigrationApi/migrationResource.wor: The `migrationResource.workflowRuleSearchPost` endpoint returns the configurations for workflow transition rules that have been migrated from server to cloud and are owned by the calling Connect app. It takes an `Atlassian-Transfer-Id` parameter to identify the app migration transfer and a `WorkflowRulesSearch` body to specify the search criteria. You'd use this endpoint to retrieve information about the workflow rules that have been migrated as part of an app migration process.
v3/AppPropertiesApi/addonPropertiesResou: The `addonPropertiesResource.deleteAddonPropertyDelete` endpoint is used to delete an app's property. It requires the `addonKey` and `propertyKey` parameters, and can only be accessed by the Connect app whose key matches the `addonKey` or by Forge apps accessing the Connect app properties. This endpoint is useful when you need to remove a specific app property from the system.

The `addonPropertiesResource.getAddonPropertiesGet` endpoint retrieves all the properties of a Jira app, given the `addonKey` parameter. It requires either OAuth2 or basic authentication, and the app key must match the provided `addonKey`. This endpoint is useful for Jira app developers who need to access the properties of their own app.

The `addonPropertiesResource.getAddonPropertyGet` endpoint retrieves the key and value of a specific app property, given the app key and property key. This endpoint is primarily used by Connect apps or Forge apps to access the properties of other Connect apps. Access to this endpoint is restricted and requires appropriate permissions.

The `addonPropertiesResource.putAddonPropertyPut` endpoint allows you to set the value of an app's property, which can be used to store custom data for your app. You provide the `addonKey` and `propertyKey` to identify the property, and the request body must be a valid, non-empty JSON blob with a maximum length of 32768 characters. This endpoint is useful for Connect apps and Forge apps that need to store and manage custom configuration data.
v3/AppPropertiesApi/deleteForgeAppProper: The `deleteForgeAppProperty` endpoint in the AppPropertiesApi allows you to delete a Forge app's property. It requires the `propertyKey` parameter to specify the key of the property to be deleted. This API can only be accessed using `asApp()` requests from Forge apps, and the `write:app-data:jira` OAuth scope is recommended, though not yet mandatory.
v3/AppPropertiesApi/getForgeAppProperty: The `getForgeAppProperty` endpoint retrieves the value of a Forge app's property. It requires the `propertyKey` parameter and can only be accessed using `asApp()` requests from Forge apps. This endpoint is used when you need to fetch a specific property associated with a Forge app.
v3/AppPropertiesApi/getForgeAppPropertyK: The `getForgeAppPropertyKeys` endpoint in the Jira API retrieves all the property keys for a Forge app. This is useful for Forge apps that need to access their own app properties. The endpoint can only be accessed using the `asApp()` method from the Forge API and requires the appropriate permissions.
v3/AppPropertiesApi/putForgeAppProperty: The `putForgeAppProperty` endpoint allows you to set the value of a Forge app's property. These property values can be retrieved in Jira expressions and entity property display conditions. The request body must be a valid, non-empty JSON blob with a maximum length of 32768 characters. This endpoint can only be accessed using Forge app requests and requires the `write:app-data:jira` OAuth scope (which will eventually be mandatory).
v3/ApplicationRolesApi/getAllApplication: The `getAllApplicationRoles` endpoint retrieves all application roles in Jira. It requires the *Administer Jira* global permission and can be accessed using either OAuth2 or basic authentication. This endpoint is useful for administrators to manage and configure application access in Jira.
v3/ApplicationRolesApi/getApplicationRol: The `getApplicationRole` endpoint in the Jira API retrieves a specific application role based on the provided `key` parameter. This endpoint is useful when you need to access the details of a particular application role, such as when managing user permissions or configuring application settings. It requires the "Administer Jira" global permission.
v3/AuditRecordsApi/getAuditRecords: The `getAuditRecords` endpoint in the AuditRecordsApi retrieves a list of audit records that can be filtered by various parameters, such as `offset`, `limit`, `filter`, `from`, and `to`. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve and analyze audit logs, for example, to investigate security incidents or monitor user activities within your Jira instance. The endpoint requires the "Administer Jira" global permission.
v3/AvatarsApi/deleteAvatar: The `deleteAvatar` endpoint in the AvatarsApi allows you to delete an avatar associated with a project, issue type, or priority in Jira. It requires the `Administer Jira` global permission and takes in the avatar type, the owning object ID, and the avatar ID as parameters. This endpoint is useful when you need to remove an avatar that is no longer needed or appropriate for a particular Jira entity.
v3/AvatarsApi/getAllSystemAvatars: The `getAllSystemAvatars` endpoint retrieves a list of system avatars by owner type, such as issue type, project, user, or priority. It can be accessed anonymously and doesn't require any permissions.
v3/AvatarsApi/getAvatarImageByID: The `getAvatarImageByID` endpoint in the AvatarsApi retrieves an avatar image by its ID. Key parameters include the type of avatar (issuetype, project, or priority), the avatar ID, and optional parameters to specify the desired size and format of the returned image. This endpoint is used to fetch avatar images for various Jira entities, such as projects, issue types, and priorities, and can be accessed anonymously or with appropriate permissions.
v3/AvatarsApi/getAvatarImageByOwner: The `getAvatarImageByOwner` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to retrieve the avatar image for a project, issue type, or priority. You can specify the type of avatar, the entity ID it belongs to, the desired size, and the image format. This endpoint can be accessed anonymously or with appropriate permissions, depending on the avatar type.
v3/AvatarsApi/getAvatarImageByType: The `getAvatarImageByType` endpoint in the AvatarsApi allows you to retrieve the default project, issue type, or priority avatar image. You can specify the type, size, and format of the avatar image you want to retrieve. This endpoint can be accessed anonymously and is useful for retrieving the default avatar images used in your Jira application.
v3/AvatarsApi/getAvatars: The `getAvatars` endpoint in the AvatarsApi retrieves the system and custom avatars for a project, issue type, or priority. It requires the `Browse projects` permission for the associated project(s) and can be accessed anonymously. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve the available avatars for a specific entity in your Jira instance.
v3/AvatarsApi/storeAvatar: The `storeAvatar` endpoint in the AvatarsApi is used to load a custom avatar for a project, issue type, or priority in Jira. It takes parameters like the avatar type, entity ID, size, and optional cropping coordinates to define the avatar image. This endpoint is typically used when you want to set a custom avatar for a specific Jira entity, such as a project, issue type, or priority.
v3/ClassificationLevelsApi/getAllUserDat: The `getAllUserDataClassificationLevels` endpoint retrieves all data classification levels, optionally filtering by status (published, archived, or draft) and ordering the results by rank. This endpoint can be used to get the available data classification levels for your application.
v3/DashboardsApi/addGadget: The `addGadget` endpoint in the DashboardsApi allows you to add a gadget to a specific dashboard. It takes a `dashboardId` parameter to identify the dashboard and a `DashboardGadgetSettings` object to configure the gadget. This endpoint can be used to customize the contents of a dashboard.
v3/DashboardsApi/bulkEditDashboards: The `bulkEditDashboards` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to bulk edit up to 100 dashboards at a time. You would use this endpoint when you need to update multiple dashboards, such as changing their permissions or other properties. The endpoint requires a `BulkEditShareableEntityRequest` object as a parameter and returns a `BulkEditShareableEntityResponse` object.
v3/DashboardsApi/copyDashboard: The `copyDashboard` endpoint in the DashboardsApi allows you to create a copy of an existing dashboard. You can provide new details for the copied dashboard, and optionally extend admin-level permissions to the user making the request. This endpoint is useful when you need to create a new dashboard based on an existing one, while customizing its properties.
v3/DashboardsApi/createDashboard: The `createDashboard` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to create a new dashboard. The key parameters are `DashboardDetails`, which contains the details of the dashboard to be created, and `extendAdminPermissions`, which determines whether admin-level permissions are used for the operation. This endpoint is useful when you need to programmatically create a new dashboard in your Jira instance.
v3/DashboardsApi/deleteDashboard: The `deleteDashboard` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to delete a dashboard by providing its ID. This operation requires no specific permissions, but the dashboard must be owned by the user making the request. You would use this endpoint to remove a dashboard that is no longer needed or relevant.
v3/DashboardsApi/deleteDashboardItemProp: The `deleteDashboardItemProperty` endpoint allows you to delete a dashboard item property in Jira. It requires the `dashboardId`, `itemId`, and `propertyKey` parameters. This endpoint is useful when you need to remove a specific property associated with a dashboard item, and you have the necessary edit permissions on the dashboard.
v3/DashboardsApi/getAllAvailableDashboar: The `getAllAvailableDashboardGadgets` endpoint retrieves a list of all available gadgets that can be added to any dashboard. This endpoint requires no parameters and returns an `AvailableDashboardGadgetsResponse` object, which can be used to populate a list of available gadgets in a dashboard management interface.
v3/DashboardsApi/getAllDashboards: The `getAllDashboards` endpoint in the Jira API's DashboardsApi retrieves a list of dashboards owned by or shared with the user. It supports filtering the dashboards to include only favorites or those owned by the user. This endpoint can be used to retrieve a paginated list of dashboards, with options to specify the starting index and maximum number of results per page.
v3/DashboardsApi/getAllGadgets: The `getAllGadgets` endpoint in the DashboardsApi retrieves a list of dashboard gadgets based on the specified parameters, such as dashboard ID, module keys, URIs, or gadget IDs. This operation can be used to retrieve gadgets for a specific dashboard, by module key, by URI, or by a list of gadget IDs. It can be accessed anonymously and does not require any specific permissions.
v3/DashboardsApi/getDashboard: The `getDashboard` endpoint in the DashboardsApi retrieves a dashboard by its ID. Key parameters include the `id` parameter that specifies the dashboard to retrieve. This endpoint can be used to access a dashboard that is either shared with the user or owned by the user, and is often used to retrieve a specific dashboard for display or analysis purposes.
v3/DashboardsApi/getDashboardItemPropert: The `getDashboardItemProperty` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to retrieve the key and value of a dashboard item property. This can be useful when working with dashboard items, which are user-specific gadgets that can be added to a user's dashboard. You would use this endpoint when you need to access the configuration or content details of a specific dashboard item.

The `getDashboardItemPropertyKeys` endpoint in the Jira API retrieves the keys of all properties for a dashboard item. This is useful when you need to access the properties associated with a specific dashboard item. The endpoint requires the `dashboardId` and `itemId` parameters, and the user must have read permission for the dashboard or have the dashboard shared with them.
v3/DashboardsApi/getDashboardsPaginated: The `getDashboardsPaginated` endpoint in the DashboardsApi allows you to search for and retrieve a paginated list of dashboards based on various filtering criteria such as dashboard name, owner, group, project, and status. You can use this endpoint to retrieve dashboards that match specific attributes, and control the order and pagination of the results. This can be useful when you need to display a list of dashboards in a user interface or perform advanced dashboard management tasks.
v3/DashboardsApi/removeGadget: The `removeGadget` endpoint in the DashboardsApi removes a specific gadget from a dashboard. It requires the `dashboardId` and `gadgetId` as parameters. This operation can be useful when you need to remove a gadget from a dashboard, such as when reorganizing or customizing the dashboard layout.
v3/DashboardsApi/setDashboardItemPropert: The `setDashboardItemProperty` endpoint in the Jira API is used to set the value of a dashboard item property. This is useful for storing custom data associated with a specific dashboard item in a Jira instance. The key parameters are the `dashboardId`, `itemId`, and `propertyKey`, along with the JSON-formatted `body` containing the property value. This endpoint is typically used by Jira Connect add-ons to store configuration details or content for a dashboard item.
v3/DashboardsApi/updateDashboard: The `updateDashboard` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to update the details of an existing dashboard. It requires the dashboard ID and new dashboard details as input parameters. This endpoint is useful when you need to modify the configuration of a specific dashboard, such as changing its layout, components, or other properties. The operation requires the user to have ownership of the dashboard or admin-level permissions.
v3/DashboardsApi/updateGadget: The `updateGadget` endpoint in the DashboardsApi allows you to update the title, position, and color of a gadget on a dashboard. It requires the `dashboardId` and `gadgetId` parameters, as well as a `DashboardGadgetUpdateRequest` object containing the desired changes. This endpoint can be useful when you need to modify the appearance or layout of a dashboard.
v3/DefaultApi/getWorklogsByIssueIdAndWor: The `getWorklogsByIssueIdAndWorklogId` endpoint retrieves worklog details for a list of issue ID and worklog ID pairs. This is an internal API that requires ASAP authentication and is used for bulk fetching worklogs by their issue and worklog IDs, with the returned list limited to 1,000 items. You would use this endpoint when you need to quickly fetch detailed worklog information for a large number of issues and worklogs.
v3/DynamicModulesApi/dynamicModulesResou: The `dynamicModulesResource.getModulesGet` endpoint retrieves all modules registered dynamically by the calling Connect app. This endpoint requires no parameters and returns a `ConnectModules` object, which can be used to manage and interact with the registered modules.

The `dynamicModulesResource.registerModulesPost` endpoint allows you to register a list of modules with Jira. This is primarily used by Connect apps to register their modules. The endpoint takes a `ConnectModules` object as input, which contains the details of the modules to be registered. This endpoint is typically used when you need to integrate your application with Jira and make its functionality available to Jira users.

The `dynamicModulesResource.removeModulesDelete` endpoint in the Jira API is used to remove one or more dynamic modules registered by the calling Connect app. It takes a `moduleKey` parameter that can be provided multiple times to remove specific modules. This endpoint would be used when a Connect app needs to unregister dynamic modules it had previously added to Jira.
v3/FilterSharingApi/addSharePermission: The `addSharePermission` endpoint in the FilterSharingApi allows you to add a share permission to a filter. It requires the `Share dashboards and filters` global permission and the user must own the filter. The endpoint takes the filter ID and a `SharePermissionInputBean` object as parameters, and returns a list of `SharePermission` objects representing the updated share permissions for the filter.
v3/FilterSharingApi/deleteSharePermissio: The `deleteSharePermission` endpoint in the FilterSharingApi deletes a share permission from a Jira filter. It requires the filter ID and the permission ID as parameters, and you'd use it when you need to remove a user's or group's access to a specific filter.
v3/FilterSharingApi/getDefaultShareScope: The `getDefaultShareScope` endpoint retrieves the default sharing settings for new filters and dashboards for the current user. This endpoint can be used to determine the default visibility and access level for newly created Jira resources.
v3/FilterSharingApi/getSharePermission: The `getSharePermission` endpoint in the FilterSharingApi retrieves a specific share permission for a given filter. Key parameters are `id` (the ID of the filter) and `permissionId` (the ID of the share permission). This endpoint can be used to access information about how a filter is shared, such as with which groups, projects, or the public.
v3/FilterSharingApi/getSharePermissions: The `getSharePermissions` endpoint in the FilterSharingApi returns the share permissions for a given filter. This can include sharing with groups, projects, all logged-in users, or the public. The endpoint can be accessed anonymously, and the returned permissions depend on the user's access to the filter. This operation would be used to retrieve the sharing configuration for a particular filter.
v3/FilterSharingApi/setDefaultShareScope: The `setDefaultShareScope` endpoint in the FilterSharingApi allows you to set the default sharing scope for new filters and dashboards for a user. This is useful when you need to programmatically manage the default sharing settings for a user's Jira filters and dashboards. The endpoint takes a `DefaultShareScope` object as a parameter and returns the updated `DefaultShareScope` object.
v3/FiltersApi/changeFilterOwner: The `changeFilterOwner` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to change the owner of a filter. It requires the filter ID and the account ID of the new owner as parameters. This endpoint is useful when you need to transfer ownership of a filter to a different user, either due to a change in responsibilities or if the original owner is no longer active.
v3/FiltersApi/createFilter: The `createFilter` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to create a new filter. The key parameters are the `Filter` object, which defines the properties of the new filter, and optional parameters like `expand` to include additional information in the response, and `overrideSharePermissions` to override share permissions. This endpoint would be used when you need to programmatically create a new custom filter in Jira.
v3/FiltersApi/deleteFavouriteForFilter: The `deleteFavouriteForFilter` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to remove a filter as a favorite for the user. The key parameters are `id` (the ID of the filter) and `expand` (which can be used to include additional information about the filter in the response, such as shared users and subscriptions). This endpoint would be used when a user wants to remove a filter from their list of favorites.
v3/FiltersApi/deleteFilter: The `deleteFilter` endpoint in the FiltersApi allows you to delete a specific filter in Jira, identified by its `id` parameter. This endpoint requires either OAuth2 or basic authentication, and the user deleting the filter must be the creator of the filter or have the "Administer Jira" global permission.
v3/FiltersApi/getColumns: The `getColumns` endpoint in the FiltersApi retrieves the columns configured for a specific filter. This is useful when you need to display the filter's results in a list view with the configured columns. The endpoint requires the filter ID as a parameter and returns a list of `ColumnItem` objects. The API can be accessed anonymously, but the column details are only returned for filters the user has access to.
v3/FiltersApi/getFavouriteFilters: The `getFavouriteFilters` endpoint in the Jira API returns the visible favorite filters of the user. Key parameters include `expand`, which allows you to include additional information about the filter in the response, such as shared users and subscriptions. You would use this endpoint to retrieve the user's favorite filters, which can be useful for surfacing personalized search options or providing a starting point for further filtering.
v3/FiltersApi/getFilter: The `getFilter` endpoint in the Jira API retrieves a specific filter, identified by its ID. Key parameters include `expand` to include additional information such as shared users and subscriptions, and `overrideSharePermissions` to enable returning filters with any share permissions. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve the details of a particular filter, such as its owner, sharing settings, and subscriptions.
v3/FiltersApi/getFiltersPaginated: The `getFiltersPaginated` endpoint in the Jira API is used to search for and retrieve a paginated list of filters. It allows you to filter the results based on various parameters such as filter name, owner, group, project, and more. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve a specific set of filters or when you want to display a list of filters in a user interface.
v3/FiltersApi/getMyFilters: The `getMyFilters` endpoint in the FiltersApi retrieves the filters owned by the user, and optionally includes the user's favorite filters. The `expand` parameter can be used to include additional information about the filters, such as the shared users and subscriptions. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve and manage the user's personal filters in a Jira application.
v3/FiltersApi/resetColumns: The `resetColumns` endpoint in the FiltersApi resets the user's column configuration for a filter to the default. This is useful when you need to restore the default column layout for a filter that a user has customized. The endpoint requires the ID of the filter and only works for filters that the user has permission to access.
v3/FiltersApi/setColumns: The `setColumns` endpoint in the Jira API's FiltersApi allows you to set the columns for a given filter. It takes the filter ID and a list of field IDs as input parameters. You would use this endpoint to customize the columns displayed in a filter's search results, as only navigable fields can be set as columns.
v3/FiltersApi/setFavouriteForFilter: The `setFavouriteForFilter` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to add a filter as a favorite for the current user. You can specify the filter ID and optionally expand the response to include information about shared users and subscriptions to the filter. This endpoint is useful when you need to mark a specific filter as a favorite for a user.
v3/FiltersApi/updateFilter: The `updateFilter` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to update an existing filter. You can change the filter's name, description, JQL query, or sharing permissions. To use this endpoint, you need to own the filter and have permission to access Jira. The key parameters are the `id` of the filter to update and the `Filter` object containing the new details. This endpoint is useful when you need to modify an existing Jira filter programmatically.
v3/GroupAndUserPickerApi/findUsersAndGro: The `findUsersAndGroups` endpoint in the GroupAndUserPickerApi allows you to search for users and groups based on a query string. Key parameters include `maxResults` to limit the number of results, `fieldId` to search for users and groups associated with a custom field, and `projectId` and `issueTypeId` to filter the results by project and issue type permissions. This endpoint is typically used to populate suggestion lists for picker fields in Jira.
v3/GroupsApi/addUserToGroup: The `addUserToGroup` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to add a user to a group. It requires the `UpdateUserToGroupBean` object, which specifies the user to be added, and either the `groupname` or `groupId` parameter to identify the group. This endpoint is useful when you need to grant a user access to a specific group within Jira, and requires site administration permissions.
v3/GroupsApi/bulkGetGroups: The `bulkGetGroups` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to retrieve a paginated list of groups based on various parameters such as group ID, group name, access type, and application key. This endpoint is useful when you need to fetch detailed information about multiple groups at once, and can be used with the appropriate permissions to browse users and groups.
v3/GroupsApi/createGroup: The `createGroup` endpoint in the GroupsApi allows you to create a new group in Jira. The only required parameter is an `AddGroupBean` object that contains the name of the new group. This endpoint is useful when you need to programmatically manage group memberships and permissions in your Jira instance, and requires site administration permissions to use.
v3/GroupsApi/findGroups: The `findGroups` endpoint in the GroupsApi allows you to search for groups whose names contain a specific query string. You can exclude certain groups from the results by providing a list of group names or IDs. This endpoint is typically used to populate a group picker suggestions list, and it returns a `FoundGroups` object that includes the matched groups with the query term highlighted in the group name.
v3/GroupsApi/getGroup: The `getGroup` endpoint in the GroupsApi retrieves information about a group in Jira, including the list of users in the group. Key parameters are `groupname` or `groupId` to specify the group, and `expand` to include additional fields. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve group details, such as for user management or access control purposes.
v3/GroupsApi/getUsersFromGroup: The `getUsersFromGroup` endpoint in the GroupsApi retrieves a paginated list of users in a specified group. Key parameters include `groupname` or `groupId` to identify the group, `includeInactiveUsers` to include inactive users, `startAt` to specify the page offset, and `maxResults` to limit the number of results per page. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve a list of users belonging to a specific group in Jira.
v3/GroupsApi/removeGroup: The `removeGroup` endpoint in the GroupsApi allows you to delete a Jira group. You can either specify the group name or ID, and optionally transfer any restrictions associated with the group to another group. This endpoint requires site administration permissions and is used when you need to remove a group from the Jira instance.
v3/GroupsApi/removeUserFromGroup: The `removeUserFromGroup` endpoint in the GroupsApi of the Jira API allows you to remove a user from a group. This operation requires site administration permissions (i.e., the user must be a member of the 'site-admin' group). You can specify the group by its name or ID, and the user by their account ID. This endpoint is useful when you need to remove a user from a group, such as when a user's permissions need to be revoked or changed.
v3/IssueAttachmentsApi/addAttachment: The `addAttachment` endpoint in the IssueAttachmentsApi allows you to add one or more attachments to a Jira issue. The only required parameter is the `issueIdOrKey`, which specifies the ID or key of the issue to which the attachments will be added. This endpoint is commonly used when you need to programmatically attach files to a Jira issue, such as in automated workflows or integrations.
v3/IssueAttachmentsApi/expandAttachmentF: The `expandAttachmentForHumans` endpoint in the IssueAttachmentsApi retrieves the metadata for the contents of an attachment, such as a ZIP archive, and the metadata for the attachment itself. This endpoint is used to retrieve data that is presented to the user, and it requires specific permissions to access the issue containing the attachment.

The `expandAttachmentForMachines` endpoint in the IssueAttachmentsApi retrieves the metadata for the contents of an attachment, if it is an archive (e.g., a ZIP file). This operation is useful when processing the data without presenting it to the user, as it only returns the metadata for the contents of the attachment, not the attachment itself. The required parameter is the `id` of the attachment. This operation requires the "Browse projects" project permission and any necessary issue-level security permissions.
v3/IssueAttachmentsApi/getAttachment: The `getAttachment` endpoint in the IssueAttachmentsApi retrieves the metadata of an attachment, without returning the attachment itself. This can be used to get information about an attachment, such as its ID, filename, and size, when you don't need the actual attachment file. The endpoint requires the attachment ID as a parameter and can be accessed anonymously or with the appropriate project and issue-level permissions.
v3/IssueAttachmentsApi/getAttachmentCont: The `getAttachmentContent` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to download the contents of a specific attachment. It takes the attachment ID as a parameter and can optionally handle redirects. You would use this endpoint when you need to retrieve the actual file content of an attachment, such as when a user wants to download an attachment associated with a Jira issue.
v3/IssueAttachmentsApi/getAttachmentMeta: The `getAttachmentMeta` endpoint retrieves the current attachment settings for the Jira instance, including whether attachments are enabled and the maximum attachment size allowed. This information can be useful when building applications that interact with Jira attachments, as it allows you to understand the constraints and capabilities of the attachment system. The endpoint can be accessed anonymously and does not require any parameters.
v3/IssueAttachmentsApi/getAttachmentThum: The `getAttachmentThumbnail` endpoint in the IssueAttachmentsApi allows you to retrieve the thumbnail of an attachment in Jira. Key parameters include the attachment ID, whether to redirect, fallback to a default thumbnail, and the desired thumbnail dimensions. This endpoint is useful when you need to display thumbnail previews of attachments, such as in a search index or file manager.
v3/IssueAttachmentsApi/removeAttachment: The `removeAttachment` endpoint in the IssueAttachmentsApi deletes an attachment from a Jira issue. It requires either the "Delete own attachments" or "Delete all attachments" project permission, depending on whether the attachment was created by the calling user or any user. This endpoint is useful for removing unwanted or outdated attachments from Jira issues.
v3/IssueBulkOperationsApi/getAvailableTr: The `getAvailableTransitions` endpoint in the IssueBulkOperationsApi retrieves a list of available transitions for the specified issues that can be used for bulk transition operations. It takes issue IDs or keys, and optional pagination parameters `endingBefore` and `startingAfter`. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve the available transitions for multiple issues at once, as it can handle up to 1,000 issues in a single request.
v3/IssueBulkOperationsApi/getBulkEditabl: The `getBulkEditableFields` endpoint in the Jira API is used to retrieve a list of fields that are editable in a bulk edit operation. It takes in parameters such as `issueIdsOrKeys`, `searchText`, `endingBefore`, and `startingAfter` to filter and paginate the response. This endpoint is useful when you need to perform bulk edit operations on Jira issues and need to determine which fields are eligible for editing.
v3/IssueBulkOperationsApi/getBulkOperati: The `getBulkOperationProgress` endpoint retrieves the progress status of a specified bulk issue operation task. You would use this endpoint to monitor the progress of a bulk operation, such as a global bulk change, and get information like the task ID, status (running or complete), progress percentage, and details on the issues processed. This endpoint requires the global bulk change permission.
v3/IssueBulkOperationsApi/submitBulkDele: The `submitBulkDelete` endpoint in the IssueBulkOperationsApi allows you to delete up to 1,000 issues in a single operation. It requires the global bulk change permission, the delete issues permission in all affected projects, and the browse project permission in all affected projects. You would use this endpoint to efficiently delete a large number of issues in your Jira instance.
v3/IssueBulkOperationsApi/submitBulkEdit: The `submitBulkEdit` endpoint in the IssueBulkOperationsApi allows you to submit a bulk edit request to simultaneously edit multiple Jira issues. Key parameters include the `IssueBulkEditPayload`, which contains the issues to be edited and the new field values. This endpoint is useful when you need to make changes to a large number of Jira issues at once, up to a maximum of 1000 issues and 200 fields per request.
v3/IssueBulkOperationsApi/submitBulkMove: The `submitBulkMove` endpoint in the IssueBulkOperationsApi allows you to submit a request to bulk move multiple issues from one or more projects to a single destination project, issue type, and parent. Key parameters include the `IssueBulkMovePayload`, which specifies the issues to be moved and their target location. You would use this endpoint when you need to move a large number of issues (up to 1,000) in a single request, with various permissions required depending on the specific use case.
v3/IssueBulkOperationsApi/submitBulkTran: The `submitBulkTransition` endpoint in the Jira API is used to perform a bulk transition of issue statuses. It allows you to transition up to 1,000 issues in a single operation, provided you have the necessary permissions (global bulk change, transition issues, browse project, and issue-level security permissions). The endpoint takes an `IssueBulkTransitionPayload` object as input, which contains the details of the issues to be transitioned, and returns a `SubmittedBulkOperation` object as the response.
v3/IssueBulkOperationsApi/submitBulkUnwa: The `submitBulkUnwatch` endpoint in the IssueBulkOperationsApi allows you to unwatch up to 1,000 issues in a single operation. It requires the global bulk change permission, browse project permission in all relevant projects, and issue-level security permission to view the issues. The endpoint takes an `IssueBulkWatchOrUnwatchPayload` as input and returns a `SubmittedBulkOperation` object, which you would use when you need to perform a bulk unwatch operation on multiple issues.
v3/IssueBulkOperationsApi/submitBulkWatc: The `submitBulkWatch` endpoint in the IssueBulkOperationsApi allows you to submit a bulk watch request for up to 1,000 issues at once. It requires the global bulk change permission and browse project permission in all projects containing the selected issues, as well as issue-level security permission to view the issues. You would use this endpoint when you need to watch a large number of issues in a single operation.
v3/IssueCommentPropertiesApi/deleteComme: The `deleteCommentProperty` endpoint in the IssueCommentPropertiesApi allows you to delete a specific property from a comment. The key parameters are the `commentId` and the `propertyKey` to identify the comment and the property to be deleted. This endpoint is useful when you need to remove a custom property associated with a comment, either for all comments or for comments created by the user, depending on the user's permissions.
v3/IssueCommentPropertiesApi/getCommentP: The `getCommentProperty` endpoint in the IssueCommentPropertiesApi retrieves the value of a comment property. It requires the comment ID and property key as parameters, and the user must have the "Browse projects" project permission and any necessary issue-level security permissions to access the comment. This endpoint is useful for retrieving specific properties associated with a comment, such as metadata or additional information.

The `getCommentPropertyKeys` endpoint in the IssueCommentPropertiesApi retrieves the keys of all the properties of a specific comment. It requires the comment ID as a parameter and can be accessed anonymously, but certain permissions are required based on the project, issue-level security, and comment visibility restrictions. This endpoint can be useful when you need to retrieve information about the properties associated with a comment in a Jira issue.
v3/IssueCommentPropertiesApi/setCommentP: The `setCommentProperty` endpoint in the IssueCommentPropertiesApi allows you to create or update the value of a property for a comment in Jira. It requires the `commentId`, `propertyKey`, and a JSON body containing the property value. You would use this endpoint to store custom data associated with a comment, such as metadata or additional context.
v3/IssueCommentsApi/addComment: The `addComment` endpoint in the IssueCommentsApi allows you to add a comment to an issue in Jira.
