v3/IssueTypesApi/createIssueType: The `createIssueType` endpoint in the IssueTypesApi allows you to create a new issue type in Jira and add it to the default issue type scheme. It requires the `IssueTypeCreateBean` parameter and returns an `IssueTypeDetails` object. This endpoint is useful when you need to add a new custom issue type to your Jira instance, and you need to have the "Administer Jira" global permission to use it.
v3/IssueTypesApi/createIssueTypeAvatar: The `createIssueTypeAvatar` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to load an avatar for an issue type. Key parameters include the issue type ID, the size of the avatar, and the cropping coordinates. This endpoint is typically used when you need to set a custom avatar for an issue type in Jira.
v3/IssueTypesApi/deleteIssueType: The `deleteIssueType` endpoint in the IssueTypesApi allows you to delete an issue type in Jira. If the issue type is in use, all uses will be updated with an alternative issue type specified by the `alternativeIssueTypeId` parameter. This endpoint requires the "Administer Jira" global permission.
v3/IssueTypesApi/getAlternativeIssueType: The `getAlternativeIssueTypes` endpoint in the IssueTypesApi returns a list of issue types that can be used to replace the specified issue type. This is useful when you need to find alternative issue types that are compatible with the same workflow, field configuration, and screen schemes. You would use this endpoint when you need to migrate or change an issue type in your Jira instance.
v3/IssueTypesApi/getIssueAllTypes: The `getIssueAllTypes` endpoint retrieves a list of all issue types available in the Jira instance. The endpoint can be accessed anonymously, and the issue types returned depend on the user's permissions, such as the Administer Jira global permission or the Browse projects project permission. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve a list of all available issue types in Jira.
v3/IssueTypesApi/getIssueType: The `getIssueType` endpoint in the IssueTypesApi retrieves details about a specific issue type in Jira. It requires the ID of the issue type as a parameter and returns an `IssueTypeDetails` object. This endpoint can be accessed anonymously or with the 'Browse projects' project permission or 'Administer Jira' global permission, and is useful for fetching information about issue types in Jira.
v3/IssueTypesApi/getIssueTypesForProject: The `getIssueTypesForProject` endpoint in the IssueTypesApi retrieves the issue types for a given project. Key parameters include the project ID and an optional level to filter the issue types by (e.g., subtask, base, epic). This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve the available issue types for a project, which can be helpful for tasks like configuring project settings or displaying issue type options to users.
v3/IssueTypesApi/updateIssueType: The `updateIssueType` endpoint in the IssueTypesApi allows you to update an existing issue type in Jira. It requires the `id` of the issue type and an `IssueTypeUpdateBean` object containing the changes to be made. This endpoint is typically used by administrators who need to modify the configuration of issue types in the Jira instance.
v3/IssueVotesApi/addVote: The `addVote` endpoint in the IssueVotesApi allows you to add a user's vote to an issue in Jira. The key parameter is `issueIdOrKey`, which specifies the ID or key of the issue. You would use this endpoint when you need to programmatically add a user's vote to an issue, for example, as part of a workflow or integration.
v3/IssueVotesApi/getVotes: The `getVotes` endpoint in the IssueVotesApi retrieves details about the votes on a Jira issue. It requires the "Allow users to vote on issues" option to be enabled and the necessary project permissions. The endpoint takes the issue ID or key as a parameter and returns a `Votes` object.
v3/IssueVotesApi/removeVote: The `removeVote` endpoint in the IssueVotesApi allows you to delete a user's vote from an issue. This operation requires the "Allow users to vote on issues" option to be enabled in Jira's General configuration, and the user must have the "Browse projects" project permission for the project that the issue is in, as well as any applicable issue-level security permissions. You would use this endpoint to remove a user's vote on an issue in Jira.
v3/IssueWatchersApi/addWatcher: The `addWatcher` endpoint in the IssueWatchersApi allows you to add a user as a watcher of an issue in Jira. The key parameter is the `issueIdOrKey`, which specifies the ID or key of the issue. The `body` parameter contains the account ID of the user to be added as a watcher. This endpoint is useful when you need to programmatically add users to the watcher list of an issue, and it requires the "Allow users to watch issues" option to be enabled in Jira's general configuration.
v3/IssueWatchersApi/getIsWatchingIssueBu: The `getIsWatchingIssueBulk` endpoint in the IssueWatchersApi retrieves the watched status of a list of issues for the current user. The `IssueList` parameter specifies the list of issue IDs. This endpoint is useful when you need to check the watched status of multiple issues at once, and it requires the "Allow users to watch issues" option to be enabled in Jira's general configuration.
v3/IssueWatchersApi/getIssueWatchers: The `getIssueWatchers` endpoint in the IssueWatchersApi retrieves the watchers for a specified Jira issue. It requires the "Allow users to watch issues" option to be enabled, and the user to have the "Browse projects" and potentially "View voters and watchers" permissions. This endpoint can be used to retrieve the list of users watching a particular issue.
v3/IssueWatchersApi/removeWatcher: The `removeWatcher` endpoint in the IssueWatchersApi allows you to delete a user as a watcher of an issue. It requires the "Allow users to watch issues" option to be enabled in Jira's General configuration, as well as the "Browse projects" and "Manage watcher list" project permissions. You would use this endpoint when you need to remove a user from the watcher list of a specific issue.
v3/IssueWorklogPropertiesApi/deleteWorkl: The `deleteWorklogProperty` endpoint in the IssueWorklogPropertiesApi allows you to delete a property associated with a specific worklog for an issue. You would use this endpoint when you need to remove a property from a worklog, which can be useful for managing metadata associated with work tracking. The key parameters are `issueIdOrKey`, `worklogId`, and `propertyKey`, which identify the issue, worklog, and property to be deleted, respectively.
v3/IssueWorklogPropertiesApi/getWorklogP: The `getWorklogProperty` endpoint in the IssueWorklogPropertiesApi retrieves the value of a specific property associated with a worklog. It requires the issue ID or key, the worklog ID, and the property key as parameters. This endpoint is useful when you need to access the details of a specific property associated with a worklog, such as when you're building a feature that requires accessing or displaying worklog-related data.

The `getWorklogPropertyKeys` endpoint retrieves the keys of all properties for a given worklog associated with an issue. It requires the `Browse projects` project permission and, if the worklog has visibility restrictions, the appropriate permissions to view the worklog. This endpoint can be used to retrieve metadata about a specific worklog in the context of an issue.
v3/IssueWorklogPropertiesApi/setWorklogP: The `setWorklogProperty` endpoint in the IssueWorklogPropertiesApi allows you to set the value of a worklog property. This can be used to store custom data against a worklog. The request body must be a valid, non-empty JSON blob with a maximum length of 32768 characters. You'd use this endpoint when you need to associate additional metadata with a specific worklog for an issue.
v3/IssueWorklogsApi/addWorklog: The `addWorklog` endpoint in the IssueWorklogsApi allows you to add a worklog to an issue in Jira. The key parameters are `issueIdOrKey`, which identifies the issue, and `Worklog`, which contains the details of the worklog to be added. You would use this endpoint when you need to record the time spent working on an issue in Jira, such as for time tracking purposes.
v3/IssueWorklogsApi/bulkDeleteWorklogs: The `bulkDeleteWorklogs` endpoint in the IssueWorklogsApi allows you to delete a list of worklogs from an issue. It takes parameters such as `issueIdOrKey`, `WorklogIdsRequestBean`, `adjustEstimate`, and `overrideEditableFlag`. This endpoint is useful when you need to delete multiple worklogs at once, but it has limitations such as the maximum number of worklogs that can be deleted at once. It requires specific permissions to use, such as the "Browse projects" and "Delete all worklogs" project permissions.
v3/IssueWorklogsApi/bulkMoveWorklogs: The `bulkMoveWorklogs` endpoint in the IssueWorklogsApi allows you to move a list of worklogs from one issue to another. Key parameters include the issue ID or key, a list of worklogs to move, and options to adjust the time estimate or override the editable flag. This can be useful when you need to transfer work hours between related issues, while being aware of the various limitations of this experimental API.
v3/IssueWorklogsApi/deleteWorklog: The `deleteWorklog` endpoint in the IssueWorklogsApi allows you to delete a worklog from an issue in Jira. It requires the issue ID or key, the worklog ID, and optional parameters to adjust the issue's time estimate. You would use this endpoint when you need to remove a worklog entry, for example, if it was entered incorrectly or needs to be removed for other reasons.
v3/IssueWorklogsApi/getIdsOfWorklogsDele: The `getIdsOfWorklogsDeletedSince` endpoint in the IssueWorklogsApi retrieves the IDs and delete timestamps of worklogs that have been deleted after a specified date and time. This endpoint is useful when you need to track and manage deleted worklogs in your Jira instance. The key parameter is `since`, which allows you to specify the timestamp (in milliseconds) after which you want to retrieve the deleted worklogs. The response is paginated, with a limit of 1000 worklogs per page, and includes information about the next page of results if available.
v3/IssueWorklogsApi/getIdsOfWorklogsModi: The `getIdsOfWorklogsModifiedSince` endpoint in the IssueWorklogsApi allows you to retrieve a paginated list of IDs and update timestamps for worklogs updated after a specified date and time. The key parameters are `since` (the timestamp of the oldest worklog to return) and `expand` (to include additional worklog properties). This endpoint is useful when you need to synchronize or index updated worklogs in a search system.
v3/IssueWorklogsApi/getIssueWorklog: The `getIssueWorklog` endpoint in the Jira API retrieves the worklogs for a given issue, ordered by creation time. Key parameters include the issue ID or key, the starting index and maximum number of results to return, and optional filters for the worklog start time. This endpoint is useful for retrieving and managing the work logs associated with a specific issue in Jira, subject to the user's permissions.
v3/IssueWorklogsApi/getWorklog: The `getWorklog` endpoint in the IssueWorklogsApi retrieves a specific worklog for an issue in Jira. Key parameters include the issue ID or key, the worklog ID, and the `expand` parameter to include additional worklog properties. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve details about a specific worklog, such as for reporting or auditing purposes.
v3/IssueWorklogsApi/getWorklogsForIds: The `getWorklogsForIds` endpoint in the IssueWorklogsApi retrieves the details of a list of worklog IDs. The key parameters are `WorklogIdsRequestBean`, which contains the list of worklog IDs, and `expand`, which can be used to include additional properties of each worklog. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve detailed information about specific worklogs, subject to permissions.
v3/IssueWorklogsApi/updateWorklog: The `updateWorklog` endpoint in the IssueWorklogsApi allows you to update an existing worklog for a Jira issue. Key parameters include the issue ID or key, the worklog ID, and options to control how the estimate is adjusted. This endpoint is useful when you need to update the details of a worklog, such as the time spent or comments, for an existing Jira issue.
v3/IssuesApi/archiveIssues: The `archiveIssues` endpoint in the Jira API allows administrators to archive up to 1000 issues in a single request, using the issue ID or key. It returns details of the issues archived and any errors encountered. This endpoint requires Jira admin or site admin permissions, a Premium or Enterprise license, and can only be accessed by signed-in users.
v3/IssuesApi/archiveIssuesAsync: The `archiveIssuesAsync` endpoint in the Jira API allows administrators to archive up to 100,000 issues in a single request using a JQL (Jira Query Language) query. This can be useful for bulk archiving issues, while the task status can be managed using the `get task` and `cancel task` APIs. The endpoint requires Jira admin or site admin permissions and a Premium or Enterprise license.
v3/IssuesApi/assignIssue: The `assignIssue` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to assign an issue to a user. You can use this operation when the calling user does not have the "Edit Issues" permission but has the "Assign issue" permission for the project that the issue is in. The key parameters are the `issueIdOrKey` (the ID or key of the issue to be assigned) and the `User` object (the user that the issue is assigned to). You would use this endpoint when you need to programmatically assign an issue to a user without the full "Edit Issues" permission.
v3/IssuesApi/bulkFetchIssues: The `bulkFetchIssues` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to fetch details for a set of up to 100 issues identified by their IDs or keys. The `BulkFetchIssueRequestBean` parameter specifies the issues and fields to fetch. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve information about multiple issues at once, and you require permissions to browse the projects the issues belong to, as well as any applicable issue-level security permissions.
v3/IssuesApi/createIssue: The `createIssue` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to create a new issue or subtask. Key parameters include `IssueUpdateDetails` to define the content of the issue, and `updateHistory` to control whether the project is added to the user's recently viewed project list. This endpoint is useful when you need to programmatically create new issues or subtasks in Jira.
v3/IssuesApi/createIssues: The `createIssues` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to bulk create up to 50 issues and subtasks. You can set the issue fields, apply transitions, and set issue properties. This is useful when you need to create multiple issues or subtasks at once, rather than creating them individually.
v3/IssuesApi/deleteIssue: The `deleteIssue` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to delete an issue, optionally including any subtasks associated with that issue. The key parameters are `issueIdOrKey` (the ID or key of the issue to be deleted) and `deleteSubtasks` (a boolean flag to indicate whether subtasks should also be deleted). You would use this endpoint when you need to permanently remove an issue from your Jira instance, typically as part of your issue management workflow.
v3/IssuesApi/doTransition: The `doTransition` endpoint in the IssuesApi performs an issue transition in Jira, allowing you to update the fields on the transition screen. Key parameters include the issue ID or key, and the `IssueUpdateDetails` object that contains the field updates. This endpoint is useful when you need to programmatically transition issues and update their fields as part of a workflow.
v3/IssuesApi/editIssue: The `editIssue` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to edit an existing issue. You can update the issue's fields using the `update` and `fields` properties, and set the parent field by key or ID. This endpoint is useful when you need to modify an issue in Jira, such as updating its status, assignee, or other properties. The endpoint requires the "Browse projects" and "Edit issues" project permissions, and can be accessed anonymously.
v3/IssuesApi/exportArchivedIssues: The `exportArchivedIssues` endpoint in the IssuesApi allows Jira admins to retrieve details of all archived issues and export them to a CSV file. It supports filtering the archived issues by various criteria such as projects, archival details, issue types, and reporters. The endpoint returns a response indicating the progress of the export task, and the admin who submitted the request will receive an email with a link to download the exported CSV file.
v3/IssuesApi/getBulkChangelogs: The `getBulkChangelogs` endpoint in the IssuesApi allows you to fetch changelogs for multiple issues and filter them by specific fields. It returns a paginated list of changelogs sorted by changelog date and issue IDs, starting from the oldest changelog and smallest issue ID. You can request up to 1000 issues and filter by up to 10 field IDs. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve change history for a large number of issues and filter the results based on specific fields.
v3/IssuesApi/getChangeLogs: The `getChangeLogs` endpoint in the IssuesApi retrieves a paginated list of all changelogs for a specified issue, sorted by date in ascending order. Key parameters include the `issueIdOrKey` to identify the issue, `startAt` to specify the starting index of the results, and `maxResults` to limit the number of results returned. This endpoint is useful when you need to access the change history for a specific issue, such as for audit or reporting purposes.
v3/IssuesApi/getChangeLogsByIds: The `getChangeLogsByIds` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to retrieve changelogs for an issue specified by a list of changelog IDs. This is useful when you need to access the change history of an issue. The key parameters are the `issueIdOrKey` (the ID or key of the issue) and the `IssueChangelogIds` (the list of changelog IDs). This endpoint can be accessed anonymously, but requires the "Browse projects" project permission and issue-level security permission to view the issue.
v3/IssuesApi/getCreateIssueMeta: The `getCreateIssueMeta` endpoint in the IssuesApi retrieves metadata about creating issues, including details of projects, issue types, and the create screen fields for each issue type. This information can be used to populate requests for creating new issues. The endpoint allows filtering by project IDs/keys and issue type IDs/names, and supports the `expand` parameter to include additional details about the issue creation fields.
v3/IssuesApi/getCreateIssueMetaIssueType: The `getCreateIssueMetaIssueTypeId` endpoint in the IssuesApi retrieves the create field metadata for a specified project and issue type ID. This information can be used to populate requests for creating issues or bulk creating issues. The endpoint requires the "Create issues" project permission and supports optional pagination parameters `startAt` and `maxResults`.

The `getCreateIssueMetaIssueTypes` endpoint retrieves a paginated list of issue type metadata for a specified project. This information can be used to populate the requests in the "Create issue" and "Create issues" endpoints. The key parameters are `projectIdOrKey`, `startAt`, and `maxResults`, which allow you to specify the project and control the pagination of the response.
v3/IssuesApi/getEditIssueMeta: The `getEditIssueMeta` endpoint in the IssuesApi returns the edit screen fields for an issue that are visible to and editable by the user. This information can be used to populate the requests in the Edit issue endpoint. The endpoint has optional parameters to override screen security and editability flags, which can be used by Connect and Forge apps with the Administer Jira global permission.
v3/IssuesApi/getEvents: The `getEvents` endpoint in the IssuesApi retrieves all issue events. This endpoint requires the *Administer Jira* global permission and can be used to retrieve a list of IssueEvent objects. It supports both OAuth2 and basic authentication.
v3/IssuesApi/getIssue: The `getIssue` endpoint in the IssuesApi retrieves the details of a Jira issue identified by its ID or key. It allows you to specify which fields, properties, and expansions to include in the response. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve detailed information about a specific issue, such as its summary, comments, and any recent updates.
v3/IssuesApi/getIssueLimitReport: The `getIssueLimitReport` endpoint in the IssuesApi retrieves a report of issues that are breaching or approaching per-issue limits. This can be useful for administrators to identify and manage issues that are nearing or exceeding certain limits. The optional `isReturningKeys` parameter allows you to get the issue keys instead of the issue IDs in the response. This endpoint requires the "Browse projects" project permission or the "Administer Jira" global permission to access the full results.
v3/IssuesApi/getTransitions: The `getTransitions` endpoint in the Jira API returns the transitions that can be performed on an issue, based on the issue's status. Key parameters include `issueIdOrKey` to specify the issue, `expand` to include additional information about the transitions, and `transitionId` to get a specific transition. This endpoint is useful when you need to understand the available transitions for an issue and their associated fields, which can be used to transition the issue.
v3/IssuesApi/notify: The `notify` endpoint in the IssuesApi allows you to send a notification email for a specific issue. The endpoint requires the `issueIdOrKey` parameter to identify the issue and a `Notification` object to specify the notification details. This endpoint is useful when you need to programmatically send notifications to users about issues in your Jira instance.
v3/IssuesApi/unarchiveIssues: The `unarchiveIssues` endpoint in the IssuesApi allows administrators to unarchive up to 1000 issues in a single request using issue IDs or keys. It returns details of the issues that were unarchived and any errors encountered. This endpoint is used when you need to restore archived issues in Jira, and requires Jira admin or site admin permissions with a Premium or Enterprise license.
v3/JQLApi/getAutoComplete: The `getAutoComplete` endpoint in the JQLApi retrieves field reference data for JQL (Jira Query Language) searches. This includes a list of JQL-reserved words, as well as documentation on available fields and functions, which can be used to assist with programmatic creation or validation of JQL queries. This endpoint can be accessed anonymously and does not require any parameters.
v3/JQLApi/getAutoCompletePost: This endpoint retrieves reference data for JQL (Jira Query Language) searches, including a list of JQL-reserved words, custom fields, and collapsed fields. It can filter the custom fields returned by project and provides information to assist with the programmatic creation or validation of JQL queries. This endpoint requires no special permissions and can be used to fetch the necessary data for building a custom JQL query builder.
v3/JQLApi/getFieldAutoCompleteForQuerySt: The `getFieldAutoCompleteForQueryString` endpoint in the JQLApi retrieves JQL search auto-complete suggestions for a specified field. You can provide the field name, a partial field value, a CHANGED operator predicate name, and a partial predicate value to get relevant suggestions. This endpoint can be used to provide auto-complete functionality in a Jira search interface.
v3/JQLApi/migrateQueries: The `migrateQueries` endpoint in the JQLApi converts user identifiers (username or user key) in JQL queries to their equivalent account IDs. This can be useful when you need to make your stored JQL queries GDPR-compliant. The endpoint takes a `JQLPersonalDataMigrationRequest` object as input and returns a `ConvertedJQLQueries` object with the modified queries.
v3/JQLApi/parseJqlQueries: The `parseJqlQueries` endpoint in the JQLApi of the Jira API allows you to parse and validate JQL (Jira Query Language) queries. It takes a `validation` parameter to specify the validation behavior and a `JqlQueriesToParse` object containing the queries to be parsed. This endpoint is useful when you need to validate and understand the structure of JQL queries programmatically.
v3/JQLApi/sanitiseJqlQueries: The `sanitiseJqlQueries` endpoint in the Jira API sanitizes one or more JQL (Jira Query Language) queries by converting readable details into IDs where a user doesn't have permission to view the entity. This is useful when you need to make queries GDPR-compliant by removing user identifiers from the queries. The endpoint takes a `JqlQueriesToSanitize` object as input and returns a `SanitizedJqlQueries` object as output, with the sanitized queries.
v3/JQLFunctionsAppsApi/getPrecomputation: The `getPrecomputations` endpoint from the `JQLFunctionsAppsApi` retrieves the list of precomputations (apps) for a given function, including information about when they were created, updated, and last used. You would use this endpoint to inspect the precomputed values for your app's custom JQL functions.

The `getPrecomputationsByID` endpoint in the JQLFunctionsAppsApi retrieves function precomputations by their IDs, along with information about when they were created, updated, and last used. This endpoint is specifically designed for apps, and the response includes the JQL fragment to replace the custom function clause. The API supports optional sorting of the results by various fields such as `functionKey`, `used`, `created`, and `updated`.
v3/JQLFunctionsAppsApi/updatePrecomputat: The `updatePrecomputations` endpoint in the `JQLFunctionsAppsApi` allows Forge/Connect apps to update the precomputation value of a JQL function. This endpoint is used to maintain the precomputation data for custom JQL functions, which can improve the performance of JQL queries that use these functions. The key parameter is the `JqlFunctionPrecomputationUpdateRequestBean`, which contains the details of the precomputation to be updated.
v3/JiraExpressionsApi/analyseExpression: The `analyseExpression` endpoint in the JiraExpressionsApi allows you to analyze and validate Jira expressions. It provides options to perform a syntax check, a type check (experimental), and a complexity check (experimental) on the provided Jira expressions. This endpoint is useful when you need to ensure the correctness and performance of Jira expressions, such as in the context of advanced automation or integration scenarios.
v3/JiraExpressionsApi/evaluateJSISJiraEx: The `evaluateJSISJiraExpression` endpoint in the JiraExpressionsApi allows you to evaluate a Jira expression and return its value. It uses the enhanced search API for better performance and scalability compared to the `eval` API. You can use this endpoint to test Jira expressions or fetch data in a flexible way, and it supports various context variables like `user`, `issue`, `project`, `sprint`, etc. The endpoint can be accessed anonymously, but the expression may return different results for different users depending on their permissions.
v3/JiraExpressionsApi/evaluateJiraExpres: The `evaluateJiraExpression` endpoint is used to evaluate a Jira expression and return its value. This endpoint can be used to test Jira expressions or fetch data in a flexible way. The request can include context variables like the current user, issue, project, or sprint, which can be used in the expression. The endpoint supports both OAuth2 and basic authentication, and the expression may return different results depending on the user's permissions.
v3/JiraSettingsApi/getAdvancedSettings: The `getAdvancedSettings` endpoint in the JiraSettingsApi retrieves the advanced settings for a Jira instance. This endpoint requires the *Administer Jira* global permission and does not take any parameters. You would use this endpoint to retrieve the application properties that are accessible on the *Advanced Settings* page in Jira, which can be useful for monitoring or configuring the Jira instance.
v3/JiraSettingsApi/getApplicationPropert: The `getApplicationProperty` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to retrieve application properties, either a specific property by its key or a list of all editable application properties. Key parameters include `key` to specify the property, `permissionLevel` to filter the results, and `keyFilter` to filter the list of properties by a regular expression on the key. This endpoint is typically used to access and manage Jira application settings and configurations.
v3/JiraSettingsApi/getConfiguration: The `getConfiguration` endpoint in the JiraSettingsApi retrieves the global settings in Jira, which determine the availability of optional features like subtasks and time tracking. This endpoint does not require any parameters and returns a `Configuration` object, and can be used when you need to access the Jira global settings programmatically.
v3/JiraSettingsApi/setApplicationPropert: The `setApplicationProperty` endpoint in the JiraSettingsApi allows you to change the value of an application property in Jira. Key parameters include the `id` (the property to update) and the `SimpleApplicationPropertyBean` (the new value to set). You would use this endpoint to customize various Jira settings, such as the issue clone prefix, date and time formats, and look and feel options.
v3/LabelsApi/getAllLabels: The `getAllLabels` endpoint in the Jira API returns a paginated list of all labels used in the system. Key parameters include `startAt` to control pagination and `maxResults` to limit the number of labels returned per page. This endpoint is useful for retrieving a comprehensive list of all labels in the system, which can be helpful for various reporting and administrative tasks.
v3/LicenseMetricsApi/getApproximateAppli: The `getApproximateApplicationLicenseCount` endpoint in the LicenseMetricsApi retrieves the approximate number of user accounts for a specific Jira application. It takes the `applicationKey` parameter to identify the Jira application and returns a `LicenseMetric` object. This API is useful for administrators to get an estimate of the license usage for their Jira deployment, which can be helpful for license management purposes.
v3/LicenseMetricsApi/getApproximateLicen: The `getApproximateLicenseCount` endpoint in the LicenseMetricsApi provides the approximate number of user accounts across all Jira licenses. This information is cached with a 7-day lifecycle and may be stale at the time of the call. The endpoint requires the "Administer Jira" global permission.
v3/LicenseMetricsApi/getLicense: The `getLicense` endpoint in the LicenseMetricsApi retrieves the licensing information about the Jira instance. This endpoint does not require any parameters and can be used to get details about the Jira license, such as the license type, expiration date, and user count. This would be useful for monitoring and managing the Jira instance's licensing status.
v3/Models/ActorInputBean: The ActorInputBean model represents a set of default actors (users and/or groups) that can be added to Jira issues. The key parameters are `group`, `groupId`, and `user`, which allow specifying the groups and/or individual users to be added as default actors. This model is likely used when creating or updating Jira issues, to specify the default assignees or watchers.
v3/Models/ActorsMap: The ActorsMap model defines the properties for adding users or groups to an actor map. Key parameters include `group`, `groupId`, and `user`, which allow you to specify the groups and users to be added. This model would be used when managing the actors associated with a Jira entity, such as a project or issue.
v3/Models/AddAtlassianTeamRequest: The `AddAtlassianTeamRequest` model represents the properties needed to create a new Atlassian team, including its capacity, ID, issue source ID, planning style, and sprint length. You would use this model when creating a new Atlassian team within your application.
v3/Models/AddFieldBean: The AddFieldBean model represents a field to be added to a Jira search index. The key property is `fieldId`, which specifies the ID of the field to add. This model would be used when configuring the fields that should be indexed for searching Jira issues.
v3/Models/AddGroupBean: The AddGroupBean model represents a group to be added to Jira. The key property is the `name` field, which specifies the name of the group. This model would be used when adding a new group to the Jira system.
v3/Models/AddNotificationsDetails: The `AddNotificationsDetails` model represents a set of notification events to be added to a notification scheme. It contains a list of `NotificationSchemeEventDetails` objects, which define the specific notification events and their configurations.
v3/Models/AddSecuritySchemeLevelsRequest: The AddSecuritySchemeLevelsRequestBean model represents a request to add security scheme levels to a security scheme. The key property is the "levels" list, which contains the security scheme levels to be added. This model would be used when you need to programmatically add new security scheme levels to an existing security scheme in the Jira system.
v3/Models/AnnouncementBannerConfiguratio: The AnnouncementBannerConfiguration model represents the configuration of an announcement banner, including its visibility, dismissibility, and message. This model would be used to manage and display announcement banners in an application.

The `AnnouncementBannerConfigurationUpdate` model is used to update the configuration of an announcement banner, including whether it can be dismissed, if it is enabled, the message text, and its visibility (public or private).
v3/Models/AppWorkflowTransitionRule: The `AppWorkflowTransitionRule` model represents a rule that controls the behavior of a workflow transition in a Jira app. It includes properties such as the rule's configuration, ID, key, and the associated workflow transition. This model is useful for managing and customizing the behavior of workflow transitions in Jira apps.
v3/Models/Application: The Application model represents a Jira application, with properties for the application name and type. The name is used to display a tooltip for the application's icon, while the type is used by registered rendering apps. This model would be used in features that involve displaying or managing applications within the Jira ecosystem.
v3/Models/ApplicationProperty: The `ApplicationProperty` model represents a Jira application property, which includes its ID, key, name, description, default value, allowed values, data type, and current value. This model is used to retrieve and update application properties in Jira, which can be useful for configuring and customizing Jira installations.
v3/Models/ApplicationRole: The `ApplicationRole` model represents an application role in Jira, which defines the groups that are granted default access and the details of those groups. Key properties include the role's key, name, associated groups, license information (such as number of seats and remaining seats), and whether the role is selected by default. This model is useful for managing and configuring application roles in Jira.
v3/Models/ApprovalConfiguration: The ApprovalConfiguration model in the Jira API represents the configuration for an approval workflow, including whether it is active, how the required approval count is calculated, which roles are excluded as approvers, and the transitions to be executed when a request is approved or rejected.
v3/Models/ApprovalConfigurationPreview: The `ApprovalConfigurationPreview` model represents the preview of an approval configuration, including the active approval configuration, the transition ID for approved state, and the transition ID for rejected state. This model is useful for configuring and managing approval workflows in your application.
v3/Models/ArchiveIssueAsyncRequest: The `ArchiveIssueAsyncRequest` model represents a request to archive issues asynchronously in Jira, with the optional `jql` parameter to specify the issues to be archived.
v3/Models/ArchivedIssuesFilterRequest: The `ArchivedIssuesFilterRequest` model is used to filter archived Jira issues based on various criteria such as the user who archived the issue, the date range the issue was archived, the issue type, the project, and the reporter. This model is likely used when you need to retrieve a subset of archived issues that match specific conditions.
v3/Models/AssociateFieldConfigurationsWi: The `AssociateFieldConfigurationsWithIssueTypesRequest` model is used to associate field configurations with issue types. It contains a `mappings` property, which is a set of `FieldConfigurationToIssueTypeMapping` objects that define the mappings between field configurations and issue types. This endpoint would be used to configure the field settings for different issue types in a Jira project.
v3/Models/AssociateSecuritySchemeWithPro: This endpoint/model associates an issue security scheme with a project. Key parameters include the project ID, the scheme ID to associate, and a list of old-to-new security level mappings. This would be used to configure the security scheme for a given project.
v3/Models/AssociatedItemBean: The `AssociatedItemBean` model represents an associated record, including its ID, name, parent ID, parent name, and type name. This model is likely used when retrieving or working with related items in the Jira API, such as when navigating the relationships between different entities.
v3/Models/AssociationContextObject: The `AssociationContextObject` model represents an object that provides context for an association. It has two key properties: `identifier`, which is an object, and `type`, which is a string. This model would be used when needing to store and retrieve association-related data in a Jira API implementation.
v3/Models/Attachment: The Attachment model represents the properties of an attachment in the Jira API, including the author, content, creation date, file name, ID, MIME type, self URL, size, and thumbnail URL. This model is used when interacting with attachments in Jira, such as when retrieving or managing attachment data.
v3/Models/AttachmentArchive: The `AttachmentArchive` model represents a collection of attachment entries, along with metadata about the size and availability of the archive. This model is likely used when retrieving a list of attachments, such as when searching or browsing for attachments in a Jira project. The `entries` property contains the actual attachment data, while the other properties provide information about the size and completeness of the archive.
v3/Models/AttachmentArchiveEntry: The `AttachmentArchiveEntry` model represents a single entry in an attachment archive, providing details such as the abbreviated name, index, media type, name, and size of the attachment. This model would be used when working with attachment archives in the Jira API.
v3/Models/AttachmentArchiveImpl: The `AttachmentArchiveImpl` model represents an attachment archive, containing a list of `AttachmentArchiveEntry` objects and the total number of entries. This model would be used when retrieving or working with attachment archives in the Jira API.
v3/Models/AttachmentArchiveItemReadable: The `AttachmentArchiveItemReadable` model represents a single item within an attachment archive, providing information about its index, label, media type, path, and size. This model is typically used when retrieving details about the contents of an attachment archive in a Jira issue.
v3/Models/AttachmentArchiveMetadataReada: The `AttachmentArchiveMetadataReadable` model provides information about an attachment archive, including the list of items included in the archive, the ID and MIME type of the attachment, the name of the archive file, and the total number of items in the archive. This model would be used when retrieving information about an attachment archive in a Jira application.
v3/Models/AttachmentMetadata: The `AttachmentMetadata` model provides details about an attachment in Jira, including the author, content URL, creation date, filename, ID, MIME type, additional properties, URL of the attachment metadata, size, and thumbnail URL. This model is useful when you need to retrieve information about a specific attachment in Jira.
v3/Models/AttachmentSettings: The `AttachmentSettings` model represents the configuration for attachment functionality in the system, including whether attachments are enabled and the maximum size limit for uploaded attachments. This model would be used to retrieve or update the global attachment settings.
v3/Models/AuditRecordBean: The `AuditRecordBean` model represents an audit record in Jira, containing information about changes and events that have occurred in the system. Key properties include the associated items, changed values, event source, and summary. This model would be used when retrieving or working with audit data in Jira.
v3/Models/AuditRecords: The AuditRecords model represents a paginated response of audit records, with properties for limiting the number of records, specifying the offset, and retrieving the total number of records and the list of audit record details. This model is used when retrieving a set of audit records from the Jira system.
v3/Models/AutoCompleteSuggestion: The AutoCompleteSuggestion model represents a suggested item for autocomplete, with a displayName that highlights the matching text and a value. This model would be used in autocomplete functionality, where users are provided with suggested options as they type.
v3/Models/AutoCompleteSuggestions: The `AutoCompleteSuggestions` model represents a list of suggested items for an autocomplete feature, which can be used to provide users with real-time suggestions as they type in a search field.
v3/Models/AvailableDashboardGadget: The `AvailableDashboardGadget` model represents information about a gadget that can be added to a Jira dashboard, including the module key, title, and URI of the gadget type. This model would be used when retrieving a list of available gadgets to display on a dashboard.
v3/Models/AvailableDashboardGadgetsRespo: The `AvailableDashboardGadgetsResponse` model represents a list of available dashboard gadgets that can be used to customize a Jira dashboard. The `gadgets` property contains the list of `AvailableDashboardGadget` objects, which describe the available gadgets.
v3/Models/AvailableWorkflowConnectRule: The `AvailableWorkflowConnectRule` model represents a workflow connect rule, which defines properties like the add-on key, module key, rule key, and URLs for creating, editing, and viewing the rule. This model is used to retrieve information about available workflow connect rules, which can be useful when integrating with Jira's workflow system.
v3/Models/AvailableWorkflowForgeRule: The `AvailableWorkflowForgeRule` model represents a workflow forge rule, providing details such as the rule description, unique identifier, name, key, and type. This model is useful when working with workflow automation and integrations in Jira.
v3/Models/AvailableWorkflowSystemRule: The `AvailableWorkflowSystemRule` model represents a workflow system rule, providing information about its description, compatibility with other rules, availability for initial transitions, visibility, name, key, and type. This model is useful when working with workflow configurations and rules in a Jira project.
v3/Models/AvailableWorkflowTriggerTypes: The `AvailableWorkflowTriggerTypes` model represents a trigger rule for a Jira workflow, with properties for the rule's description, name, and type. This model is used to retrieve the available workflow trigger types, which can be useful for configuring and managing Jira workflows.
v3/Models/AvailableWorkflowTriggers: The `AvailableWorkflowTriggers` model represents the available workflow trigger types and their associated rule keys. This model is used to retrieve the list of available trigger types and the corresponding rule keys, which can be useful when configuring workflow rules in a Jira application.
v3/Models/Avatar: The `Avatar` model represents information about an avatar icon in Jira, including its file name, ID, deletability, selection status, and whether it is a system avatar. This model is useful for retrieving and managing avatar information, such as when displaying or updating a user or project's avatar.
v3/Models/AvatarUrlsBean: The AvatarUrlsBean model represents the URLs of an item's avatars in various sizes (16x16, 24x24, 32x32, 48x48). This model is typically used when retrieving information about an item (e.g., a user or project) that has an associated avatar.
v3/Models/Avatars: The `Avatars` model represents a collection of custom and system avatars, which can be used to retrieve and manage user profile images. You would use this model when needing to access or update the available avatar options for a Jira application.
v3/Models/BoardColumnPayload: The `BoardColumnPayload` model represents the configuration of a column in a Jira board, including its name, minimum and maximum issue constraints, and associated status IDs. This model is likely used when creating or updating a board column through the Jira API.
v3/Models/BoardFeaturePayload: The `BoardFeaturePayload` model represents a feature for a board, with a `featureKey` property to identify the feature and a `state` property to indicate whether the feature should be turned on or off. This model would be used when configuring or updating the features associated with a board in a Jira application.
v3/Models/BoardPayload: The `BoardPayload` model represents the configuration settings for a Jira board, including the JQL filter, card color strategy, card layout, columns, features, name, project identifier, quick filters, sprint support, swimlanes, and working days configuration. This model is used when creating or updating a Jira board.
v3/Models/BoardsPayload: The `BoardsPayload` model represents a collection of `BoardPayload` objects, which are used to associate boards with a project. This model is likely used when creating or updating a project to specify the boards that should be associated with it.
v3/Models/BulkChangeOwnerDetails: The `BulkChangeOwnerDetails` model allows you to change the owner of an issue in bulk, specifying the new owner's account ID. It also indicates whether the issue name should be automatically fixed if it's duplicated after the owner change.
v3/Models/BulkChangelogRequestBean: The BulkChangelogRequestBean model allows you to fetch a list of changelogs for a set of specified issue IDs or keys, with the ability to filter by field IDs and control the maximum number of results and pagination. This model is useful when you need to retrieve detailed change history information for multiple issues in a single request.
v3/Models/BulkChangelogResponseBean: The `BulkChangelogResponseBean` model represents a response containing a list of issue changelogs and a token to fetch the next page of results. It is used when retrieving a large number of issue changes in a paginated manner.
v3/Models/BulkContextualConfiguration: The `BulkContextualConfiguration` model represents the field configuration and schema for a custom field within a specific field context. This model is used to manage the configuration and schema for multiple custom fields in bulk operations. You would use this model when updating or retrieving the configuration settings for custom fields in your Jira application.
v3/Models/BulkCustomFieldOptionCreateReq: The BulkCustomFieldOptionCreateRequest model is used to create multiple custom field options in a single request. The key parameter is the `options` property, which is a list of CustomFieldOptionCreate objects that contain the details of the options to be created. This model would be used when you need to add multiple custom field options to a project or issue at once.
v3/Models/BulkCustomFieldOptionUpdateReq: The `BulkCustomFieldOptionUpdateRequest` model is used to update multiple custom field options in Jira. The key parameter is `options`, which is a list of `CustomFieldOptionUpdate` objects that contain the details of the options to be updated. This endpoint would be used when you need to update multiple custom field options at once, such as when managing a large number of custom fields in your Jira instance.
v3/Models/BulkEditActionError: The `BulkEditActionError` model represents errors that occurred during a bulk edit operation, including a list of error messages and a map of specific errors. This model would be used when handling the response from a bulk edit API endpoint to provide detailed information about any issues that arose during the operation.
v3/Models/BulkEditGetFields: The `BulkEditGetFields` model represents the list of fields available for bulk editing in Jira. It includes properties for pagination, such as `endingBefore` and `startingAfter`, and a `fields` property that contains a list of `IssueBulkEditField` objects describing the available fields. This model would be used when retrieving the list of fields that can be edited in bulk for Jira issues.
v3/Models/BulkEditShareableEntityRequest: The `BulkEditShareableEntityRequest` model is used to perform bulk edit operations on shareable entities in Jira, such as changing the owner or permissions of multiple entities at once. Key parameters include the action to be performed, the entity IDs to be changed, and optional details for changing the owner or permissions. This model would be used when you need to make bulk changes to shareable entities in Jira, such as when migrating projects or updating permissions for multiple items at once.
v3/Models/BulkEditShareableEntityRespons: The `BulkEditShareableEntityResponse` model represents the response from a bulk edit operation on shareable entities, providing the allowed action and a mapping of entity IDs to any errors encountered during the operation.
v3/Models/BulkFetchIssueRequestBean: The `BulkFetchIssueRequestBean` model is used to fetch a set of issues from the Jira API, allowing you to specify which fields, expand options, and issue properties to include in the response. The key parameters are `issueIdsOrKeys`, which specifies the issues to fetch, and `fields` and `expand`, which control the information returned for each issue. This model is useful when you need to retrieve a batch of issues efficiently, rather than making individual requests.
v3/Models/BulkIssueIsWatching: The `BulkIssueIsWatching` model represents a map of issue IDs to their respective watching status (true/false). This model is used to manage the watching status of multiple issues in a bulk operation, which can be useful when you need to update the watching status of a large number of issues in a single request.
v3/Models/BulkIssuePropertyUpdateRequest: The `BulkIssuePropertyUpdateRequest` model is used to update issue properties in bulk. It allows setting a property value using a Jira expression, filtering the issues to update, and providing a value for the property. This endpoint would be used when you need to update a specific property across multiple issues in a single request.
v3/Models/BulkIssueResults: The BulkIssueResults model represents the response from a Jira API request to retrieve multiple issues. It includes a list of the requested issues as well as a list of any issues that could not be returned due to errors or constraints. This model is useful when you need to retrieve and work with multiple Jira issues simultaneously.
v3/Models/BulkOperationErrorResponse: The `BulkOperationErrorResponse` model represents the error response for a bulk operation, containing a list of `ErrorMessage` objects that provide details on any errors encountered during the operation. This model would be used when handling the response from Jira API endpoints that support performing bulk actions.
v3/Models/BulkOperationErrorResult: The `BulkOperationErrorResult` model represents the result of a bulk operation, including details about any errors that occurred during the operation, such as the specific elements that failed and the overall status code. This model is typically used when performing batch updates or creations of multiple objects through the Jira API.
v3/Models/BulkOperationProgress: The `BulkOperationProgress` model represents the progress of a bulk operation in Jira, such as a mass update or transition. It provides details on the status, progress, and results of the operation, including the number of issues processed, failed, and inaccessible, as well as the specific issues and reasons for failure. This model would be used when monitoring or reporting on the status of a long-running bulk operation.
v3/Models/BulkPermissionGrants: The `BulkPermissionGrants` model represents a collection of global and project-specific permissions granted to a user. It provides a way to manage and retrieve the user's access privileges across the entire system and specific projects.
v3/Models/BulkPermissionsRequestBean: The BulkPermissionsRequestBean model is used to request information about a user's global and project-specific permissions in Jira. It allows you to specify the account ID of the user, a set of global permissions to look up, and a set of project permissions along with associated projects and issues. This model is useful when you need to efficiently retrieve a user's permission details across multiple Jira entities.
v3/Models/BulkProjectPermissionGrants: The `BulkProjectPermissionGrants` model represents the project permissions granted to a user, including the specific issues and projects they have access to. This model is useful for managing and auditing user permissions across multiple projects and issues in a Jira instance.
v3/Models/BulkProjectPermissions: The `BulkProjectPermissions` model represents a set of project permissions associated with a list of issues and projects. It allows you to manage permissions in bulk, specifying the affected issues, projects, and the permissions to be applied.
v3/Models/BulkRedactionRequest: The `BulkRedactionRequest` model represents a request to redact multiple entities, with the `redactions` property containing a set of `SingleRedactionRequest` objects that define the individual redaction operations. This endpoint would be used when needing to perform multiple redactions in a single request, such as when anonymizing or obfuscating sensitive information in a dataset.
v3/Models/BulkRedactionResponse: The BulkRedactionResponse model represents the result of a bulk redaction request, containing a set of SingleRedactionResponse objects that provide details on the individual redactions performed.
v3/Models/BulkTransitionGetAvailableTran: The BulkTransitionGetAvailableTransitions model retrieves a list of available transitions for a bulk transition operation on the requested issues, grouped by workflow. It includes pagination properties to allow for retrieving the results in chunks. This would be used when you need to perform a bulk transition on multiple issues and want to get the available transition options first.
v3/Models/BulkTransitionSubmitInput: The BulkTransitionSubmitInput model is used to perform a bulk transition on a list of Jira issues, allowing you to transition multiple issues at once by specifying the issue IDs or keys and the ID of the transition to be performed.
v3/Models/BulkWorklogKeyRequestBean: The BulkWorklogKeyRequestBean model represents a list of issue and worklog ID pairs, which can be used to retrieve or delete multiple worklogs in bulk. This model is useful when you need to perform bulk operations on worklogs across multiple issues.
v3/Models/BulkWorklogKeyResponseBean: The `BulkWorklogKeyResponseBean` model represents the response from a bulk worklog retrieval operation, containing a list of successfully retrieved worklogs with their associated issue and worklog IDs. This would be used when retrieving multiple worklogs at once, to efficiently obtain the relevant worklog details.
v3/Models/CardLayout: The CardLayout model represents a configuration option for a card layout, allowing you to specify whether to show days in a column. This property would be useful when designing a calendar or schedule-based view in your application.
v3/Models/CardLayoutField: The CardLayoutField model represents a field within a card layout, defined by its fieldId, id, mode, and position. This model would be used when working with the card layouts in a Jira application, such as when configuring or retrieving information about the layout of cards.
v3/Models/ChangeDetails: The `ChangeDetails` model represents the details of a change made to a field in a Jira issue, including the field name, field ID, field type, original value, and new value. This model is likely used in Jira API responses when retrieving information about changes made to issues.
v3/Models/ChangeFilterOwner: The `ChangeFilterOwner` model is used to update the owner of a Jira filter, where the `accountId` parameter specifies the new owner's account ID. This endpoint would be used to transfer ownership of a filter to a different Jira user.
v3/Models/ChangedValueBean: The ChangedValueBean model represents the details of a field change, including the previous and new values, as well as the name of the field that was changed. This model is commonly used in Jira API responses that provide information about changes made to issues or other entities.
v3/Models/ChangedWorklog: The ChangedWorklog model represents a change to a worklog in Jira. It includes the properties associated with the change, the time the change was made, and the ID of the worklog. This model would be used in Jira API responses to provide details about changes made to worklogs.
v3/Models/ChangedWorklogs: The ChangedWorklogs model represents a list of updated worklogs, with properties like the datetime range of the worklogs, the URL for the next page of results, and the list of changed worklog objects. This model would be used to track changes to worklogs over time, for example, to monitor updates to time tracking data.
v3/Models/Changelog: The Changelog model represents the details of changes made to an issue in Jira, including the author, date, metadata, and a list of the specific changes. This model would be used to retrieve and analyze the history of changes made to an issue in Jira.
v3/Models/ColumnItem: The `ColumnItem` model represents a column in the Jira issue navigator, with a `label` and `value` property. It's used to configure the columns displayed in the issue navigator.
v3/Models/ColumnRequestBody: The `ColumnRequestBody` model represents a request body that contains a list of columns. This model is typically used when you need to specify which columns to include in a search or report, such as when configuring a Jira issue search.
v3/Models/Comment: The `Comment` model represents a comment on a Jira issue. It includes properties such as the author, body, creation and update dates, visibility, and rendered content. This model would be used when interacting with the Jira API to create, update, or retrieve comments on Jira issues.
v3/Models/ComponentIssuesCount: The `ComponentIssuesCount` model represents the count of issues assigned to a component in Jira, along with the URL to retrieve this information. This model is useful when you need to retrieve the number of issues associated with a specific component.
v3/Models/ComponentJsonBean: The `ComponentJsonBean` model represents a Jira component, providing properties like `ari`, `description`, `id`, `metadata`, `name`, and `self`. This model is commonly used when working with Jira components, such as when retrieving, creating, or updating component information.
v3/Models/ComponentWithIssueCount: The `ComponentWithIssueCount` model represents a Jira project component with associated issue count information. It includes properties such as the component's assignee, assignee type, description, ID, issue count, lead, name, and project details. This model is useful when you need to retrieve information about the components within a Jira project, including the number of issues associated with each component.
v3/Models/CompoundClause: The CompoundClause model represents a compound JQL (Jira Query Language) query clause, containing a list of nested clauses and an operator to combine them. It is used to build complex search queries in Jira.
v3/Models/ConditionGroupConfiguration: The ConditionGroupConfiguration model represents a group of conditions for a workflow rule. It allows specifying nested condition groups and the operation (ANY or ALL) to determine how the conditions in the group are evaluated. This model is used when configuring workflow rules in the Jira system.
v3/Models/ConditionGroupPayload: The `ConditionGroupPayload` model represents a nested condition group that can be used in Jira's search functionality. It allows defining a set of conditions with a specified logical operation (ANY or ALL) to evaluate the condition group. This model is used to build complex search queries with multiple nested conditions.
v3/Models/ConditionGroupUpdate: The ConditionGroupUpdate model defines a condition group that can be used to configure workflow rules in Jira. It allows specifying a set of conditions, along with an operation (ANY or ALL) to determine how the conditions are evaluated. This model would be used when creating or updating workflow rules in Jira to define the specific conditions that should be checked.
v3/Models/Configuration: This endpoint/model represents the configuration settings for a Jira instance, including whether attachments, issue linking, subtasks, time tracking, unassigned issues, voting, and watching are enabled. These settings are commonly used to manage the functionality and behavior of a Jira project or instance.
v3/Models/ConfigurationsListParameters: The `ConfigurationsListParameters` model represents the parameters used to retrieve a list of configurations, allowing you to filter by a list of custom field IDs or keys. This would be used to fetch specific configurations based on the custom fields you're interested in.
v3/Models/ConnectCustomFieldValue: The `ConnectCustomFieldValue` model represents the value of a custom field in a Jira issue. It includes properties like the custom field type, ID, issue ID, and the corresponding value based on the field type (number, option ID, rich text, string, or text). This model is useful when working with custom fields in Jira, such as retrieving or updating their values.
v3/Models/ConnectCustomFieldValues: The `ConnectCustomFieldValues` model represents a list of custom field update details to be used in Jira Connect integrations. This model is typically used when updating custom field values in a Jira integration, allowing you to specify the new values for one or more custom fields.
v3/Models/ConnectModules: The `ConnectModules` model represents a list of app modules in the same format as the `modules` property in the Jira app descriptor. This model is likely used when installing or managing Jira apps that extend the platform's functionality.
v3/Models/ConnectWorkflowTransitionRule: The ConnectWorkflowTransitionRule model represents a workflow transition rule in Jira. It contains a configuration, an ID, a key, and an optional transition property. This model would be used when working with workflow rules and transitions in a Jira instance.
v3/Models/ContainerForProjectFeatures: The `ContainerForProjectFeatures` model represents a container for project features, which can be used to retrieve a list of available project features. This model is typically used in the context of project configuration or management operations.
v3/Models/ContainerForRegisteredWebhooks: The `ContainerForRegisteredWebhooks` model represents a list of registered webhooks, which can be used to manage and track the webhooks associated with an application or service.
v3/Models/ContainerForWebhookIDs: The `ContainerForWebhookIDs` model represents a container for a list of webhook IDs. You would use this model when working with Jira's Webhook API, such as when retrieving or managing a set of webhooks associated with a Jira instance.
v3/Models/ContainerOfWorkflowSchemeAssoc: The `ContainerOfWorkflowSchemeAssociations` model represents a list of workflow schemes and the projects they are associated with. You would use this model to retrieve the workflow scheme associations for a set of projects.
v3/Models/ContentItem: The `ContentItem` model represents an entity that can be redacted from Jira, such as an issue field, comment, or worklog. The `entityId` property specifies the ID of the content entity, while the `entityType` property indicates the type of entity (e.g., `issuefieldvalue`, `issue-comment`, `issue-worklog`). The `id` property represents the ID of the issue associated with the content entity. This model is likely used in APIs related to data redaction or privacy management within Jira.
v3/Models/Context: The Context model represents a context in Jira, which can have an ID, name, and scope. This model is used in the Jira API to manage and retrieve context-related information, such as when you need to retrieve or update a specific context in your application.
v3/Models/ContextForProjectAndIssueType: The `ContextForProjectAndIssueType` model represents the context of a custom field for a specific project and issue type. It includes the `contextId`, `issueTypeId`, and `projectId` properties, which are used to identify the custom field context, issue type, and project, respectively.
v3/Models/ContextualConfiguration: The ContextualConfiguration model represents the configuration and schema for a field in a specific field context. It includes the field configuration, the ID of the associated field context, the configuration ID, and the field value schema. This model is used to manage and configure fields in a Jira application.
v3/Models/ConvertedJQLQueries: The `ConvertedJQLQueries` model represents the result of converting Jira Query Language (JQL) queries to use account IDs instead of user identifiers. It includes a list of queries containing user information that could not be mapped to an existing user, and the list of converted query strings with account IDs. This model is useful when working with Jira API endpoints that require using account IDs instead of user identifiers in JQL queries.
v3/Models/CreateCrossProjectReleaseReque: The `CreateCrossProjectReleaseRequest` model is used to create a new cross-project release in Jira, specifying the release name and the IDs of the releases to include in the cross-project release. This endpoint would be used when you need to aggregate releases from multiple projects into a single cross-project release.
v3/Models/CreateCustomFieldContext: The `CreateCustomFieldContext` model represents a custom field context in Jira, which defines the projects and issue types where the custom field is available. Key properties include the context's name, description, associated issue types and projects, and a unique ID. This model is used when creating or updating custom field contexts in Jira.
v3/Models/CreateCustomFieldRequest: The `CreateCustomFieldRequest` model represents the request to create a new custom field in Jira. It includes the custom field ID and a boolean flag to enable filtering issues based on the custom field's values.
v3/Models/CreateDateFieldRequest: The `CreateDateFieldRequest` model is used to specify a date field to be included in a Jira search index. It requires a `type` parameter to indicate the type of date field (e.g., "DueDate", "TargetStartDate", "TargetEndDate", or "DateCustomField") and an optional `dateCustomFieldId` parameter if the `type` is "DateCustomField". This model is typically used when configuring search indexing in Jira.
v3/Models/CreateExclusionRulesRequest: The CreateExclusionRulesRequest model allows you to define exclusion rules for a plan by specifying issue IDs, issue type IDs, completed issues within a certain number of days, release IDs, work status category IDs, and work status IDs. You would use this model to filter out specific issues, types, statuses, and releases when generating a plan.
v3/Models/CreateIssueSecuritySchemeDetai: The `CreateIssueSecuritySchemeDetails` model represents the details required to create a new issue security scheme in Jira. It includes a name, description, and a list of security scheme levels. This model would be used when creating a new issue security scheme via the Jira API.
v3/Models/CreateIssueSourceRequest: The `CreateIssueSourceRequest` model represents the source of issues to be included in a search index. It has two key properties: `type` (specifying the source type as "Board", "Project", or "Filter") and `value` (the ID of the corresponding board, project, or filter). This model would be used when creating or updating a search index to specify the issues to be included.
v3/Models/CreateNotificationSchemeDetail: The `CreateNotificationSchemeDetails` model is used to create a new notification scheme in Jira. It allows you to specify the scheme's name, description, and the list of notification events that should be included in the scheme. This endpoint would be used when you need to set up custom notification rules for your Jira projects.
v3/Models/CreatePermissionHolderRequest: The `CreatePermissionHolderRequest` model defines the request body for creating a new permission holder in Jira. It requires a `type` parameter that must be either "Group" or "AccountId", and a `value` parameter that must be a group name or an account ID depending on the `type`.
