It requires the `taskId` parameter to identify the task, and returns a `TaskProgressBeanObject` containing the task details. This endpoint is useful when you need to check the progress or status of an asynchronous task that was previously created, such as a task that performs a complex operation in the background.
v3/TeamsInPlanApi/addAtlassianTeam: The `addAtlassianTeam` endpoint in the TeamsInPlanApi allows you to add an existing Atlassian team to a plan and configure their planning settings. It requires the "Administer Jira" global permission. The key parameter is the `planId`, which identifies the plan to which the team will be added.
v3/TeamsInPlanApi/createPlanOnlyTeam: The `createPlanOnlyTeam` endpoint in the TeamsInPlanApi allows you to create a plan-only team and configure their planning settings. You would use this endpoint when you need to create a new team that will be associated with a specific plan. The endpoint requires a `planId` and a `CreatePlanOnlyTeamRequest` object as input parameters, and it returns the ID of the created team.
v3/TeamsInPlanApi/deletePlanOnlyTeam: The `deletePlanOnlyTeam` endpoint in the `TeamsInPlanApi` allows you to delete a plan-only team and their planning settings. It requires the `Administer Jira` global permission and takes the `planId` and `planOnlyTeamId` as input parameters. This endpoint would be used when you need to remove a plan-only team from a project plan.
v3/TeamsInPlanApi/getAtlassianTeam: The `getAtlassianTeam` endpoint in the TeamsInPlanApi retrieves the planning settings for an Atlassian team within a specific plan. It requires the `planId` and `atlassianTeamId` parameters, and the user needs the "Administer Jira" global permission to access this endpoint. The response is a `GetAtlassianTeamResponse` object.
v3/TeamsInPlanApi/getPlanOnlyTeam: The `getPlanOnlyTeam` endpoint in the TeamsInPlanApi retrieves the planning settings for a specific plan-only team in Jira. It requires the `planId` and `planOnlyTeamId` as parameters, and the `Administer Jira` global permission to use. This endpoint would be used to fetch detailed information about a plan-only team's configuration within a Jira project plan.
v3/TeamsInPlanApi/getTeams: The `getTeams` endpoint in the TeamsInPlanApi retrieves a paginated list of plan-only and Atlassian teams in a plan. It requires the 'Administer Jira' global permission. Key parameters include the plan ID, a cursor for pagination, and the maximum number of results to return per page.
v3/TeamsInPlanApi/removeAtlassianTeam: The `removeAtlassianTeam` endpoint removes an Atlassian team from a plan and deletes their planning settings. It requires the `Administer Jira` global permission and takes the `planId` and `atlassianTeamId` as parameters. This endpoint would be used to remove an Atlassian team from a plan when their planning settings are no longer needed.
v3/TeamsInPlanApi/updateAtlassianTeam: The `updateAtlassianTeam` endpoint in the `TeamsInPlanApi` allows you to update the planning settings of an Atlassian team in a plan, such as the planning style, issue source ID, sprint length, and capacity. This endpoint accepts a JSON Patch document as the request body and requires the "Administer Jira" global permission. You would use this endpoint when you need to modify the configuration of an Atlassian team within a specific plan.
v3/TeamsInPlanApi/updatePlanOnlyTeam: The `updatePlanOnlyTeam` endpoint in the TeamsInPlanApi allows you to update the planning settings of a plan-only team in Jira using JSON Patch. This includes updating the team's name, planning style, issue source, sprint length, capacity, and member account IDs. You would use this endpoint when you need to modify the configuration of a plan-only team in a Jira plan.
v3/TimeTrackingApi/getAvailableTimeTrack: The `getAvailableTimeTrackingImplementations` endpoint in the TimeTrackingApi retrieves a list of all the time tracking providers available in the Jira instance. This is useful when you need to understand the different time tracking options configured in your Jira instance, such as the default "Jira provided time tracking" and any additional time tracking providers installed via Atlassian Marketplace apps. This endpoint requires the "Administer Jira" global permission.
v3/TimeTrackingApi/getSelectedTimeTracki: The `getSelectedTimeTrackingImplementation` endpoint retrieves the current time tracking provider in Jira. This endpoint requires the "Administer Jira" global permission and can be used when the time tracking feature is enabled in Jira.
v3/TimeTrackingApi/getSharedTimeTracking: The `getSharedTimeTrackingConfiguration` endpoint in the TimeTrackingApi retrieves the time tracking settings for a Jira instance, including the time format, default time unit, and other related configurations. This endpoint requires the `Administer Jira` global permission and can be used to access the time tracking settings of the Jira instance.
v3/TimeTrackingApi/selectTimeTrackingImp: The `selectTimeTrackingImplementation` endpoint in the TimeTrackingApi allows you to select a time tracking provider for your Jira instance. This is a POST request that requires the "Administer Jira" global permission. The only parameter is the `TimeTrackingProvider` object, which specifies the time tracking provider to be selected.
v3/TimeTrackingApi/setSharedTimeTracking: The `setSharedTimeTrackingConfiguration` endpoint in the TimeTrackingApi allows you to set the time tracking settings for your Jira instance. This endpoint requires the "Administer Jira" global permission and takes a `TimeTrackingConfiguration` object as a parameter. You would use this endpoint to configure the time tracking settings for your Jira project, such as the time tracking scheme, time format, and other related settings.
v3/UIModificationsAppsApi/createUiModifi: The `createUiModification` endpoint in the `UIModificationsAppsApi` allows you to create a UI modification for a Jira app. Key parameters include the `CreateUiModificationDetails` object, which contains the details of the UI modification. You would use this endpoint when you want to define custom UI modifications for your Jira app, such as adding custom fields or modifying existing UI elements.
v3/UIModificationsAppsApi/deleteUiModifi: The `deleteUiModification` endpoint in the `UIModificationsAppsApi` allows you to delete a UI modification, including all its associated contexts, using the `uiModificationId` parameter. This endpoint is typically used by Forge apps to manage UI modifications. The `write:app-data:jira` OAuth scope is optional but recommended for this operation.
v3/UIModificationsAppsApi/getUiModificat: The `getUiModifications` endpoint in the `UIModificationsAppsApi` allows you to retrieve UI modifications that have been made by Forge apps. It returns a paginated response with the `PageBeanUiModificationDetails` model, which can be further customized using the `startAt`, `maxResults`, and `expand` parameters. This endpoint is primarily used by Forge apps to retrieve information about the UI modifications they have made.
v3/UIModificationsAppsApi/updateUiModifi: The `updateUiModification` endpoint in the `UIModificationsAppsApi` allows you to update a UI modification in Jira. It requires the `uiModificationId` and an `UpdateUiModificationDetails` object containing the details of the UI modification to be updated. This endpoint is used by Forge apps to update UI modifications, and the permissions required depend on whether the UI modification is created with or without contexts.
v3/UserPropertiesApi/deleteUserProperty: The `deleteUserProperty` endpoint in the UserPropertiesApi allows you to delete a property from a user's account. You can specify the property key and either the user's account ID, user key, or username to target the deletion. This endpoint is useful when you need to remove a specific user property, such as when a user's preferences or settings need to be modified.
v3/UserPropertiesApi/getUserProperty: The `getUserProperty` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to retrieve the value of a specific user property. You can specify the property key, account ID, user key, or username to retrieve the desired property. This is useful when you need to access user-specific information stored as properties, but not the general user properties managed in Jira. The endpoint requires either the 'Administer Jira' global permission or access to Jira to retrieve the property for the calling user.
v3/UserPropertiesApi/getUserPropertyKeys: The `getUserPropertyKeys` endpoint in the UserPropertiesApi retrieves the keys of all properties for a user. To use this endpoint, you need either the `Administer Jira` global permission to access any user's property keys, or access to Jira to retrieve the calling user's property keys. The endpoint accepts an `accountId`, `userKey`, or `username` parameter to specify the user.
v3/UserPropertiesApi/setUserProperty: The `setUserProperty` endpoint in the Jira UserPropertiesApi allows you to set a custom property for a user. You can specify the property key and value, along with the user's account ID, user key, or username. This is useful for storing custom data associated with a user in Jira.
v3/UserSearchApi/findAssignableUsers: The `findAssignableUsers` endpoint in the Jira API is used to find users who can be assigned to an issue. It allows you to search for users based on various parameters such as a query string, account ID, project, issue key, or issue ID. The endpoint returns a list of users who can be assigned to the specified issue or issue transition. You'd use this endpoint when you need to find the list of users who can be assigned to a new or existing issue, or during a workflow transition.
v3/UserSearchApi/findBulkAssignableUsers: The `findBulkAssignableUsers` endpoint of the UserSearchApi in the Jira API allows you to find users who can be assigned issues in one or more specified projects. The key parameters are `projectKeys`, `query`, `accountId`, `startAt`, and `maxResults`, which allow you to filter and paginate the results. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve a list of users who can be assigned issues in specific projects.
v3/UserSearchApi/findUserKeysByQuery: The `findUserKeysByQuery` endpoint in the UserSearchApi allows you to search for users based on a structured query, such as finding users who are assignees, reporters, watchers, voters, or commenters on specific issues. You can specify the range of users to return using the `startAt` and `maxResults` parameters. This endpoint is useful when you need to find users matching specific criteria within your Jira instance.
v3/UserSearchApi/findUsers: The `findUsers` endpoint in the Jira API's UserSearchApi allows you to search for active users based on various parameters like `query`, `username`, `accountId`, `startAt`, `maxResults`, and `property`. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve a list of users that match specific criteria, such as searching for users by their display name or email address.
v3/UserSearchApi/findUsersByQuery: The `findUsersByQuery` endpoint in the UserSearchApi allows you to search for users based on a structured query. Key parameters include `query` (the search query), `startAt` (the index of the first item to return), and `maxResults` (the maximum number of items to return). This endpoint is useful when you need to find users based on specific criteria, such as who is assigned to, reported on, or commented on certain issues.
v3/UserSearchApi/findUsersForPicker: The `findUsersForPicker` endpoint in the UserSearchApi allows you to search for users and return a list of users whose attributes match the provided query term. Key parameters include `query` to specify the search term, `maxResults` to limit the number of returned users, and `excludeAccountIds` to exclude specific users from the results. This endpoint is useful when you need to search for and select users, such as for an autocomplete or picker UI component.
v3/UserSearchApi/findUsersWithAllPermiss: The `findUsersWithAllPermissions` endpoint in the UserSearchApi returns a list of users who match a search string and have a set of specified permissions for a project or issue. Key parameters include `permissions`, `query`, `accountId`, `issueKey`, and `projectKey`. This endpoint is useful when you need to find users with specific permissions in a project or for an issue.
v3/UserSearchApi/findUsersWithBrowsePerm: The `findUsersWithBrowsePermission` endpoint in the Jira UserSearchApi retrieves a list of users who match a given search query and have permission to browse issues. Key parameters include `query`, `issueKey`, `projectKey`, `startAt`, and `maxResults`. This endpoint is useful for finding users who can access and view specific issues or projects in Jira.
v3/UsersApi/bulkGetUsers: The `bulkGetUsers` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to retrieve a paginated list of users specified by their account IDs. Key parameters include `accountId`, `startAt`, `maxResults`, `username`, and `key`. You would use this endpoint when you need to retrieve information about multiple users in a single request, such as for user management or reporting purposes.
v3/UsersApi/bulkGetUsersMigration: The `bulkGetUsersMigration` endpoint in the UsersApi retrieves the account IDs for the users specified by the `username` or `key` parameters. This is useful when you need to fetch user information in bulk, and can be used with permissions to access Jira.
v3/UsersApi/createUser: The `createUser` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to create a new user. It requires the `NewUserDetails` object as a parameter, which contains details about the user to be created. This endpoint is used when you need to programmatically create a new user in Jira, and it requires the `Administer Jira` global permission.
v3/UsersApi/getAllUsers: The `getAllUsers` endpoint in the Jira API's `UsersApi` retrieves a list of all users, including active, inactive, and previously deleted users with an Atlassian account. Key parameters include `startAt` (the index of the first item to return) and `maxResults` (the maximum number of items to return, limited to 1000). This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve a comprehensive list of users in a Jira instance, subject to the user's profile visibility preferences.
v3/UsersApi/getAllUsersDefault: The `getAllUsersDefault` endpoint in the Jira API's `UsersApi` allows you to retrieve a list of all users, including active, inactive, and previously deleted users with Atlassian accounts. Key parameters include `startAt` to specify the index of the first item to return, and `maxResults` to limit the number of results (up to 1000). This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve and work with the full set of users in a Jira instance, such as for user management or reporting purposes.
v3/UsersApi/getUser: The `getUser` endpoint in the Jira API's `UsersApi` returns a user's information based on their account ID, username, or key. Key parameters include `accountId`, `username`, and `key` to specify the user, and `expand` to include additional user details like their groups and application roles. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve a specific user's information in your application.
v3/UsersApi/getUserDefaultColumns: The `getUserDefaultColumns` endpoint in the Jira API retrieves the default issue table columns for a user. It takes an optional `accountId` parameter to get the columns for a specific user, or the calling user's columns if not provided. This endpoint is useful when you need to access a user's default column configuration, such as for customizing the user interface or integrating with other systems.
v3/UsersApi/getUserEmail: The `getUserEmail` endpoint retrieves a user's email address regardless of their profile visibility settings. It requires the user's account ID as a parameter. This API is only available for approved Connect apps and can be accessed via Forge app's `asApp()` requests.
v3/UsersApi/getUserEmailBulk: The `getUserEmailBulk` endpoint in the UsersApi retrieves the email addresses of users based on their account IDs, regardless of their profile visibility settings. This API is only available to Connect apps approved by Atlassian or Forge apps using the `asApp()` request. The key parameter is `accountId`, which is a unique identifier for the user across Atlassian products.
v3/UsersApi/getUserGroups: The `getUserGroups` endpoint in the Jira API returns the groups to which a user belongs, given the user's account ID. This endpoint requires the "Browse users and groups" global permission and can be used to retrieve information about a user's group membership.
v3/UsersApi/removeUser: The `removeUser` endpoint in the UsersApi of the Jira API allows you to delete a user from Jira's user base, given the user's account ID. This operation requires site administration permissions and does not delete the user's Atlassian account.
v3/UsersApi/resetUserColumns: The `resetUserColumns` endpoint in the Jira API resets the default issue table columns for a specified user to the system default. The optional `accountId` parameter can be used to reset the columns for a specific user, or the calling user's columns will be reset if `accountId` is not provided. This endpoint requires either the "Administer Jira" global permission to set columns for any user, or permission to access Jira to set the calling user's columns.
v3/UsersApi/setUserColumns: The `setUserColumns` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to set the default issue table columns for a user. You can pass the `accountId` parameter to set the columns for a specific user, or omit it to set the columns for the calling user. The endpoint accepts a `UserColumnRequestBody` object, which contains the IDs of the columns to set. This endpoint is useful when you need to programmatically manage the default column configuration for Jira users.
v3/WebhooksApi/deleteWebhookById: The `deleteWebhookById` endpoint in the WebhooksApi allows you to delete webhooks by their ID. It only removes webhooks registered by the calling app and ignores webhooks created by other apps. This endpoint is used when you need to remove specific webhooks from your app's configuration. It requires either Connect or OAuth 2.0 app permissions.
v3/WebhooksApi/getDynamicWebhooksForApp: The `getDynamicWebhooksForApp` endpoint in the WebhooksApi retrieves a paginated list of dynamic webhooks registered by the calling Connect or OAuth 2.0 app. The key parameters are `startAt` and `maxResults`, which control the pagination of the results. This endpoint would be used by apps to retrieve and manage the webhooks they have registered with Jira.
v3/WebhooksApi/getFailedWebhooks: The `getFailedWebhooks` endpoint in the WebhooksApi retrieves a list of recently failed webhooks that a Connect app can use to troubleshoot delivery issues. Key parameters include `maxResults` to limit the number of returned webhooks, and `after` to retrieve webhooks failed after a specific time. This endpoint is primarily used by Connect apps to manage and monitor their webhook delivery failures.
v3/WebhooksApi/refreshWebhooks: The `refreshWebhooks` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to extend the life of registered webhooks. This operation is useful for keeping your webhooks alive, as they expire after 30 days. The endpoint takes a `ContainerForWebhookIDs` object as a parameter, which contains the IDs of the webhooks you want to refresh. The response is a `WebhooksExpirationDate` object, which provides the new expiration date for the refreshed webhooks. This endpoint is only accessible to [Connect](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/#connect-apps) and [OAuth 2.0](https://developer.atl
v3/WebhooksApi/registerDynamicWebhooks: The `registerDynamicWebhooks` endpoint in the Jira WebhooksApi allows you to register dynamic webhooks. This is useful when you need to receive notifications about events that occur in Jira. The key parameter is the `WebhookRegistrationDetails` object, which contains the configuration for the webhook. This endpoint is typically used by Connect and OAuth 2.0 apps that need to integrate with Jira.
v3/WorkflowSchemeDraftsApi/createWorkflo: This endpoint creates a draft workflow scheme from an active workflow scheme by copying the active workflow scheme. You would use this endpoint when you need to create a draft workflow scheme to make changes to an existing workflow scheme. The key parameter is the `id` of the active workflow scheme that the draft is created from.
v3/WorkflowSchemeDraftsApi/deleteDraftDe: The `deleteDraftDefaultWorkflow` endpoint in the `WorkflowSchemeDraftsApi` allows you to reset the default workflow for a workflow scheme's draft to Jira's system workflow. You would use this endpoint when you need to modify the default workflow configuration for a workflow scheme draft, which requires the "Administer Jira" global permission.
v3/WorkflowSchemeDraftsApi/deleteDraftWo: The `deleteDraftWorkflowMapping` endpoint in the WorkflowSchemeDraftsApi allows you to delete the workflow-issue type mapping for a workflow in a workflow scheme's draft. You would use this endpoint when you need to remove the association between a workflow and its issue types in a draft workflow scheme, typically when administering the Jira instance.
v3/WorkflowSchemeDraftsApi/deleteWorkflo: The `deleteWorkflowSchemeDraft` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to delete a draft workflow scheme. You would use this endpoint when you need to remove a draft workflow scheme that was previously created. This endpoint requires the "Administer Jira" global permission.

The `deleteWorkflowSchemeDraftIssueType` endpoint in the `WorkflowSchemeDraftsApi` deletes the issue type-workflow mapping for an issue type in a workflow scheme's draft. It requires the `id` of the workflow scheme and the `issueType` to be provided as parameters. This endpoint is typically used when you need to remove a specific issue type's workflow from a draft workflow scheme.
v3/WorkflowSchemeDraftsApi/getDraftDefau: The `getDraftDefaultWorkflow` endpoint in the `WorkflowSchemeDraftsApi` retrieves the default workflow for a workflow scheme's draft. The default workflow is the workflow assigned to any issue types that have not been mapped to another workflow within the workflow scheme. This endpoint is useful when you need to access the default workflow configuration for a particular workflow scheme draft, typically for administrative or management purposes. The only required parameter is the `id` of the workflow scheme that the draft belongs to.
v3/WorkflowSchemeDraftsApi/getDraftWorkf: The `getDraftWorkflow` endpoint retrieves the workflow-issue type mappings for a draft workflow scheme. It requires the `id` of the workflow scheme and allows filtering by the `workflowName`. This endpoint is typically used when administering Jira and managing workflow schemes and their draft configurations.
v3/WorkflowSchemeDraftsApi/getWorkflowSc: The `getWorkflowSchemeDraft` endpoint in the WorkflowSchemeDraftsApi retrieves the draft workflow scheme for an active workflow scheme. This is useful when you need to make changes to an active workflow scheme, as draft workflow schemes allow modifications to be made before applying them to the active scheme. The endpoint requires the `id` of the active workflow scheme and the `Administer Jira` global permission.

The `getWorkflowSchemeDraftIssueType` endpoint retrieves the issue type-workflow mapping for a specific issue type in a workflow scheme's draft. It requires the ID of the workflow scheme and the ID of the issue type as input parameters. This endpoint would be used when you need to access the workflow configuration for a specific issue type in a draft workflow scheme, which is useful for workflows administration and customization.
v3/WorkflowSchemeDraftsApi/publishDraftW: The `publishDraftWorkflowScheme` endpoint in the WorkflowSchemeDraftsApi allows you to publish a draft workflow scheme. It requires the ID of the workflow scheme that the draft belongs to, details of the status mappings, and an optional `validateOnly` parameter to perform a validation check. This endpoint is useful when you need to publish changes to a workflow scheme draft, potentially updating existing issues with new workflow statuses.
v3/WorkflowSchemeDraftsApi/setWorkflowSc: The `setWorkflowSchemeDraftIssueType` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to set the workflow for an issue type in a workflow scheme's draft. This is useful when you need to configure the workflow for a specific issue type within a workflow scheme. The key parameters are `id` (the ID of the workflow scheme the draft belongs to), `issueType` (the ID of the issue type), and `IssueTypeWorkflowMapping` (the issue type-project mapping). This endpoint requires the "Administer Jira" global permission.
v3/WorkflowSchemeDraftsApi/updateDraftDe: The `updateDraftDefaultWorkflow` endpoint from the `WorkflowSchemeDraftsApi` is used to update the default workflow for a draft workflow scheme. It takes the `id` of the workflow scheme and a `DefaultWorkflow` object as parameters, and returns the updated `WorkflowScheme` object. This endpoint is typically used when you need to change the default workflow for a draft workflow scheme before publishing it.
v3/WorkflowSchemeDraftsApi/updateDraftWo: The `updateDraftWorkflowMapping` endpoint in the WorkflowSchemeDraftsApi is used to set the issue types for a workflow in a workflow scheme's draft. This endpoint allows you to map specific issue types to a given workflow, and can also set the workflow as the default for the draft workflow scheme. You would use this endpoint when you need to manage the issue type to workflow mappings in a draft workflow scheme.
v3/WorkflowSchemeDraftsApi/updateWorkflo: The `updateWorkflowSchemeDraft` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to update a draft workflow scheme. This is useful when you need to make changes to a workflow scheme without affecting the active one. The key parameter is the `id` of the active workflow scheme that the draft was created from. You would use this endpoint when you need to update a draft workflow scheme, for example, to modify the workflows associated with different issue types.
v3/WorkflowSchemeProjectAssociationsApi/: The `assignSchemeToProject` endpoint in the `WorkflowSchemeProjectAssociationsApi` allows you to assign a workflow scheme to a project. This operation can only be performed when there are no issues in the project, and it is applicable only for classic projects. You would use this endpoint when you need to associate a specific workflow scheme with a project.

The `getWorkflowSchemeProjectAssociations` endpoint in the Jira API returns a list of the workflow schemes associated with a list of projects. It takes a `projectId` parameter to specify the projects to include, and returns a `ContainerOfWorkflowSchemeAssociations` object that contains the associated workflow schemes. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve the workflow schemes associated with specific projects, such as for administrative purposes or to display project-level workflow information.
v3/WorkflowSchemesApi/createWorkflowSche: The `createWorkflowScheme` endpoint in the Jira API is used to create a new workflow scheme. It requires the `Administer Jira` global permission and takes a `WorkflowScheme` object as a parameter. This endpoint would be used when you need to create a new custom workflow scheme in Jira.
v3/WorkflowSchemesApi/deleteDefaultWorkf: The `deleteDefaultWorkflow` endpoint in the Jira API's `WorkflowSchemesApi` allows you to reset the default workflow for a workflow scheme. Key parameters include the `id` of the workflow scheme and an optional `updateDraftIfNeeded` parameter to create or update a draft workflow scheme if the active workflow scheme cannot be edited. This endpoint is useful when you need to reset the default workflow for a workflow scheme, particularly when the active workflow scheme cannot be directly edited.
v3/WorkflowSchemesApi/deleteWorkflowMapp: The `deleteWorkflowMapping` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to delete the workflow-issue type mapping for a workflow in a workflow scheme. This is useful when you need to remove a specific workflow from a workflow scheme. The endpoint requires the ID of the workflow scheme, the name of the workflow, and an optional parameter to create or update a draft workflow scheme if the current one is active and cannot be edited directly.
v3/WorkflowSchemesApi/deleteWorkflowSche: The `deleteWorkflowScheme` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to delete a workflow scheme. This is useful when you need to remove a workflow scheme that is no longer in use. The key parameter is the `id` of the workflow scheme, which can be found by editing the desired workflow scheme in Jira. This endpoint requires the "Administer Jira" global permission.

This endpoint allows you to delete the issue type-workflow mapping for a specific issue type in a workflow scheme. If the workflow scheme is active, you can set the `updateDraftIfNeeded` parameter to `true` to create or update a draft of the workflow scheme and make the change in the draft, which can then be published. This is useful when you need to modify the workflow for an issue type within a workflow scheme.
v3/WorkflowSchemesApi/getAllWorkflowSche: The `getAllWorkflowSchemes` endpoint in the WorkflowSchemesApi retrieves a paginated list of all workflow schemes, excluding draft workflow schemes. This endpoint requires the *Administer Jira* global permission and allows you to control the starting index and maximum number of results returned.
v3/WorkflowSchemesApi/getDefaultWorkflow: The `getDefaultWorkflow` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to retrieve the default workflow for a given workflow scheme. The key parameters are `id` (the ID of the workflow scheme) and `returnDraftIfExists` (whether to return the default workflow for the draft scheme or the published scheme). You would use this endpoint to get information about the default workflow assigned to unassigned issue types in a workflow scheme.
v3/WorkflowSchemesApi/getProjectUsagesFo: This endpoint retrieves a paginated list of projects that are using a given workflow scheme, specified by the `workflowSchemeId` parameter. Key parameters include `nextPageToken` to navigate the pagination and `maxResults` to limit the number of results returned. This endpoint would be used to determine which projects are currently using a specific workflow scheme.
v3/WorkflowSchemesApi/getRequiredWorkflo: The `getRequiredWorkflowSchemeMappings` endpoint in the WorkflowSchemesApi retrieves the required status mappings for updating a workflow scheme. It takes a `WorkflowSchemeUpdateRequiredMappingsRequest` as input and returns a `WorkflowSchemeUpdateRequiredMappingsResponse`. This endpoint is useful when you need to update a workflow scheme, as it provides the necessary information about the required status mappings for the desired changes.
v3/WorkflowSchemesApi/getWorkflow: The `getWorkflow` endpoint in the `WorkflowSchemesApi` retrieves the workflow-issue type mappings for a workflow scheme. It takes the ID of the workflow scheme, an optional workflow name to filter the results, and a flag to return the draft mapping if it exists. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve the configured issue type to workflow mappings for a particular workflow scheme.
v3/WorkflowSchemesApi/getWorkflowScheme: The `getWorkflowScheme` endpoint retrieves a workflow scheme by its ID. It allows you to optionally return the draft version of the workflow scheme instead of the published version. This endpoint is useful when you need to access the details of a specific workflow scheme, such as when managing or configuring workflows in Jira.
v3/WorkflowSchemesApi/getWorkflowSchemeI: The `getWorkflowSchemeIssueType` endpoint retrieves the issue type-workflow mapping for an issue type in a workflow scheme. It takes the workflow scheme ID, the issue type ID, and an optional parameter to return the mapping from the workflow scheme's draft if it exists. This endpoint is useful when you need to understand the workflow configured for a specific issue type within a workflow scheme.
v3/WorkflowSchemesApi/readWorkflowScheme: The `readWorkflowSchemes` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to bulk retrieve a list of workflow schemes by providing workflow scheme IDs or project IDs. This can be useful when you need to retrieve and manage multiple workflow schemes at once, such as for administrative or auditing purposes. The endpoint requires either the *Administer Jira* global permission or the *Administer projects* project permission, depending on whether you need to access project-scoped or global workflow schemes.
v3/WorkflowSchemesApi/setWorkflowSchemeI: The `setWorkflowSchemeIssueType` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to set the workflow for an issue type in a workflow scheme. This is useful when you need to update the workflow associated with a specific issue type within a workflow scheme. Key parameters include the ID of the workflow scheme, the ID of the issue type, and the new issue type-workflow mapping. This endpoint is typically used when you need to modify the workflow configuration for a specific issue type in Jira.
v3/WorkflowSchemesApi/updateDefaultWorkf: The `updateDefaultWorkflow` endpoint in the Jira Workflow Schemes API allows you to set the default workflow for a workflow scheme. Key parameters include the `id` of the workflow scheme and the `DefaultWorkflow` object containing the new default workflow. You would use this endpoint to update the default workflow for a workflow scheme, particularly when the workflow scheme is active, as it allows creating or updating a draft workflow scheme that can then be published.
v3/WorkflowSchemesApi/updateSchemes: The `updateSchemes` endpoint of the `WorkflowSchemesApi` allows you to update company-managed and team-managed project workflow schemes in Jira. It takes a `WorkflowSchemeUpdateRequest` object as a parameter and returns a generic response. This endpoint is useful when you need to update the available statuses for issue types in a workflow scheme, which triggers an asynchronous task to migrate the issues accordingly. The endpoint requires the `Administer Jira` project permission for global-scoped workflow schemes or the `Administer projects` project permission for project-scoped workflow schemes.
v3/WorkflowSchemesApi/updateWorkflowMapp: The `updateWorkflowMapping` endpoint in the WorkflowSchemesApi allows you to set the issue types for a workflow in a workflow scheme. You can also set the workflow as the default for the scheme, and it will map any unmapped issue types to the default workflow. This endpoint is useful when you need to update the workflow-issue type mappings for a workflow scheme, especially for active workflow schemes where you can create or update a draft workflow scheme.
v3/WorkflowSchemesApi/updateWorkflowSche: The `updateWorkflowScheme` endpoint in the WorkflowSchemesApi allows you to update a company-managed project workflow scheme, including its name, default workflow, and issue type to project mappings. It requires the "Administer Jira" global permission, and can create or update a draft workflow scheme if the existing one is active and `updateDraftIfNeeded` is set to `true`.
v3/WorkflowStatusCategoriesApi/getStatus: The `getStatusCategories` endpoint in the `WorkflowStatusCategoriesApi` retrieves a list of all status categories in Jira. This endpoint requires permission to access Jira and can be used to retrieve information about the available status categories in your Jira instance.

The `getStatusCategory` endpoint retrieves a specific status category in Jira. The only required parameter is `idOrKey`, which specifies the ID or key of the status category to fetch. This endpoint would be used when you need to retrieve information about a particular status category, such as its name, description, or ID, within the context of a Jira integration or application.
v3/WorkflowStatusesApi/getStatus: The `getStatus` endpoint in the `WorkflowStatusesApi` returns the details of a workflow status based on its ID or name. It can be accessed anonymously as long as the user has the 'Browse projects' permission for the project. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve information about a specific workflow status, such as when integrating with a workflow management system.
v3/WorkflowStatusesApi/getStatuses: The `getStatuses` endpoint retrieves a list of all statuses associated with active workflows in Jira. This operation can be accessed anonymously and requires the *Browse projects* project permission. The response returns a list of `StatusDetails` objects.
v3/WorkflowTransitionPropertiesApi/creat: This endpoint is used to create a new workflow transition property in Jira. The key parameters are the `transitionId`, `key`, `workflowName`, and `workflowMode`. You would use this endpoint when you need to add a new property to a workflow transition to customize its behavior, such as changing how a transition works or adding additional logic.
v3/WorkflowTransitionPropertiesApi/delet: The `deleteWorkflowTransitionProperty` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to delete a property from a workflow transition. Transition properties are used to change the behavior of a transition. You would use this endpoint to remove a specific property from a workflow transition when you need to modify the behavior of that transition. The key parameters are `transitionId`, `key`, `workflowName`, and `workflowMode` (optional).
v3/WorkflowTransitionPropertiesApi/getWo: The `getWorkflowTransitionProperties` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to retrieve the properties of a workflow transition. It takes parameters such as the transition ID, workflow name, and whether to include reserved keys. This endpoint is useful when you need to access and manage the configuration of workflow transitions, such as for advanced workflow customization or automation purposes.
v3/WorkflowTransitionPropertiesApi/updat: The `updateWorkflowTransitionProperty` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to update a workflow transition property. Key parameters include the `transitionId`, `key`, `workflowName`, and optional `workflowMode`. You would use this endpoint to modify the behavior of a workflow transition by updating its property values.
v3/WorkflowTransitionRulesApi/deleteWork: The `deleteWorkflowTransitionRuleConfigurations` endpoint allows a Connect app to delete workflow transition rules, including post functions, conditions, and validators, from one or more workflows. It takes a `WorkflowsWithTransitionRulesDetails` object as a parameter and returns a `WorkflowTransitionRulesUpdateErrors` object indicating any errors that occurred during the deletion process. This endpoint is primarily used by Connect apps to manage and remove workflow rules they have created.
v3/WorkflowTransitionRulesApi/getWorkflo: The `getWorkflowTransitionRuleConfigurations` endpoint in the Jira API returns a paginated list of workflows with transition rules that can be filtered by rule type, rule keys, workflow names, tags, and draft/published status. This endpoint is used by Connect and Forge apps to retrieve information about workflow transition rules they have created.
v3/WorkflowTransitionRulesApi/updateWork: The `updateWorkflowTransitionRuleConfigurations` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to update the configuration of workflow transition rules, including post functions, conditions, and validators. It is primarily used by Connect and Forge apps to disable rules, add tags, and assist with app migration. The endpoint requires specific permissions and the request body must be a `WorkflowTransitionRulesUpdate` object.
v3/WorkflowsApi/createWorkflow:
This endpoint allows you to create a new workflow in Jira. Key parameters include:

- `CreateWorkflowDetails`: The details of the workflow to be created, including transition rules and conditions.
- You can define various types of conditions (e.g., "always false", "block transition until approval", "compare number custom field") that control when a transition can be executed.
- This endpoint is useful when you need to create custom workflows in Jira, especially for company-managed scoped workflows.
v3/WorkflowsApi/createWorkflows: The `createWorkflows` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to bulk create workflows and their related statuses. It requires either the *Administer Jira* project permission to create global-scoped workflows, or the *Administer projects* project permissions to create project-scoped workflows. You would use this endpoint when you need to create multiple workflows at once, rather than creating them individually.
v3/WorkflowsApi/deleteInactiveWorkflow: The `deleteInactiveWorkflow` endpoint in the Jira API deletes an inactive workflow. The key parameter is `entityId`, which specifies the ID of the workflow to be deleted. You would use this endpoint to remove a workflow that is no longer in use and meets the specified conditions.
v3/WorkflowsApi/getAllWorkflows: The `getAllWorkflows` endpoint in the Jira API is used to retrieve all workflows or a specific workflow by name. This endpoint is deprecated and will be removed on February 1, 2026, so it is recommended to use the "Search workflows" endpoint instead. The endpoint requires the "Administer Jira" global permission and returns a list of workflow objects or a single workflow object if the `workflowName` parameter is provided.
v3/WorkflowsApi/getDefaultEditor: The `getDefaultEditor` endpoint in the WorkflowsApi retrieves the user's default workflow editor, which can be either the new or legacy editor. It requires no parameters and returns a `DefaultWorkflowEditorResponse` object, and is typically used to determine the user's preferred workflow editing experience.
v3/WorkflowsApi/getProjectUsagesForWorkf: The `getProjectUsagesForWorkflow` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to retrieve a paginated list of projects that are using a specific workflow. The key parameters are the `workflowId`, `nextPageToken`, and `maxResults`. This endpoint is useful when you need to understand which projects are associated with a particular workflow, such as when you're managing and maintaining workflows across your Jira instance.
v3/WorkflowsApi/getWorkflowProjectIssueT: The `getWorkflowProjectIssueTypeUsages` endpoint in the Jira API retrieves the issue types in a project that are using a given workflow. Key parameters include the `workflowId`, `projectId`, `nextPageToken`, and `maxResults`. This endpoint would be used to retrieve information about which issue types are associated with a specific workflow within a project.
v3/WorkflowsApi/getWorkflowSchemeUsagesF: The `getWorkflowSchemeUsagesForWorkflow` endpoint retrieves a paginated list of workflow schemes that are using a given workflow, with optional parameters to control the pagination. It's useful when you need to understand which workflow schemes are relying on a specific workflow.
v3/WorkflowsApi/getWorkflowsPaginated: The `getWorkflowsPaginated` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to retrieve a paginated list of published classic workflows. You can filter the workflows by name, activity status, and order them by various fields. This endpoint is useful when you need to retrieve and manage workflows in your Jira instance, for example, when building a search index or workflow management tool.
v3/WorkflowsApi/readWorkflowPreviews: The `readWorkflowPreviews` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to preview a workflow within a given project. It returns a read-only preview of the workflow, omitting full configuration details. You would use this endpoint when you need to view a workflow's details, such as when managing project configurations, without accessing the full workflow configuration.
v3/WorkflowsApi/readWorkflows: The `readWorkflows` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to bulk retrieve workflows and related statuses by providing workflow names, workflow IDs, or project and issue types. It requires either the *Administer Jira* global permission or a combination of the *Administer projects* and *View (read-only) workflow* project permissions. The `WorkflowReadRequest` parameter specifies the workflows to retrieve, and the `useApprovalConfiguration` parameter determines whether to return the new `approvalConfiguration` field instead of the deprecated status properties for approval configuration.
v3/WorkflowsApi/searchWorkflows: The `searchWorkflows` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to search for global and project workflows. It returns a paginated list of workflows, with optional filtering by name, scope (global or project-specific), and activity status. You would use this endpoint to retrieve information about the workflows configured in your Jira instance, which can be useful for tasks like workflow management or reporting.
v3/WorkflowsApi/updateWorkflows: The `updateWorkflows` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to bulk update workflows and their related statuses. It requires the `Administer Jira` project permission to create global-scoped workflows or the `Administer projects` permission to create project-scoped workflows. You would use this endpoint when you need to update multiple workflows at once, such as when making changes to your workflow configurations.
v3/WorkflowsApi/validateCreateWorkflows: The `validateCreateWorkflows` endpoint in the Jira API allows you to validate the payload for bulk creating workflows. It requires either the *Administer Jira* project permission to create global-scoped workflows or the *Administer projects* permission to create project-scoped workflows. The endpoint takes a `WorkflowCreateValidateRequest` parameter and returns a `WorkflowValidationErrorList` object, which can be used to check for any errors in the workflow creation request.
v3/WorkflowsApi/validateUpdateWorkflows: This endpoint validates the payload for a bulk update of workflows in Jira. It takes a `WorkflowUpdateValidateRequestBean` object as input and returns a `WorkflowValidationErrorList` object, which contains any errors found in the validation process. This endpoint is useful when you need to validate the changes you want to make to workflows before actually updating them.
v3/WorkflowsApi/workflowCapabilities: The `workflowCapabilities` endpoint in the Jira Workflows API allows you to retrieve the available workflow capabilities for a specific workflow, using either the workflow ID or the project and issue type ID pair. The response includes information about the workflow's scope (global/project-based), the project types it is scoped to, and the various rules (conditions, validators, actions, triggers, screens) associated with the workflow, including their source (Atlassian-provided, Connect, Forge). This endpoint is useful when you need to understand the capabilities and configurations of a specific workflow in Jira.
